I'm actually planning to gather my past publications on a blog, better organized, and maybe to then use that place to get started writing what might become a book about the Mandelbrot set.

, counting in the Mandelbrot set is fun! I'd slightly reformulate your second observation: Approaching any minibrot you find period doubling. Two arms, four, 8, 16, 32... Of course, each of these arms will contain more smaller minibrots, but these are further surrounded by a corona
which itself has a period of the kind its parent arm belongs to
And that the features that are doubled correspond to the things you saw on the approach is also a very interesting fact. Exploiting that idea is called "stacking".
Also interestingly, if you look at the generalization of the Mandelbrot set for higher powers, instead of period doubling, you'd find period n-folding instead.
And then there's an interesting way the angles of the minibrots vary when you follow a spiral.

I usually try to follow a pattern with regard to the counts, doublings, or the variation of angles. This rhythmic approach more often than not leads to appealing examples. The extra order helps the mind to grasp more depth.

been there too! Parameterising these observables is challenging, as they interleave or otherwise combine in different ways. It would be good to see these properties, e.g. spiralling, gradient, arm count (and gradients to orders), ..., Mapped as statistics on the space. That in itself would be an exercise in extracting (perhaps human) observables into those properties.
I would love to know a coordinate system for one of the tree features,

! So far it seems nobody has been able to describe more than a few linear families. I think that lack of a methodical way to construct coordinates is why people are shying away from attempts to describe what you get to see when zooming in. I think that's totally unnecessary, and I would like to build an informal dictionary instead. On the plus side you'd get to formulate lots of conjectures about the Mandelbrot set, for others to try to find answers to.

That would be interesting. I expect more formal mathematicians would keep the significance of these maps firmly tied to the initial spatial coordinates, and try to use them to converge on Riemann-Zeta problems. :)
Yes, there's so much fun stuff to dive into,

Let's define an ideal arch as one that doesn't have a tendency to fall apart sideways, outward or inward. This means no shear (sideways) stress between blocks, and that means the pressure force between blocks in contact is a normal force -- it acts along the line of the arch. That should sound familiar! For a hanging string, obviously the tension acts along the line of the string.
[…] the ideal arch shape is a catenary.

In fact, Gaudi designed a church in Barcelona using a web of strings and weights to find correct shapes for the arches -- of course, the actual building would have a shape like the reflection in a horizontal mirror above the strings.
This stuff comes from  lecture notes on mechanics in exquisite web quality (by Michael Fowler, the textbook being Landau and Lishitz'

)! Its first and a bit of its second chapter carve out the catenary as solution to a few problems for which, if you think about it, or look a bit closer at the derivations, it is not obvious at all they have the same solution!

I always use this picture in my talks on quantum computing for general audiences. Gaudi's model of Sagrada Família is a wonderful example of how nature can compute -- you just let the ropes dangle and the gravity will solve the problem for you! I like to introduce quantum computing in a similar way, except here it is quantum mechanics rather than gravity that does the job!

A more faithful extrapolation of the Mandelbrot set to 3D is this
. Like with the Mandelbrot we apply the squaring of magnitude and the +C but in 3D.
The only difficulty is the lateral part of the square operation, which takes two semi-circles and 'double covers' them onto a whole circle.

In 3D we take four spherical triangles in a tetrahedral covering of the sphere and 'quadruple cover' them onto the whole sphere in a conformal manner. Since the tetrahedron is the most even way to place quarter areas over a sphere, this is I think about the closest extrapolation of the double covering to 3D.
The resulting operation is not conformal, however it is laterally conformal and the radial expansion does equal the average lateral expansion over the whole sphere at any given radius.

Here's the remainder of my orderly comment about ordered sets:
We all know about totally ordered sets. They are sets which can be put on a line, like a chain or a necklace, a string of pearls. These can be captured by four axioms like John said:
if x≤y and y≤x then x=y
for all x,y we either have x≤y or y≤x.

And the canonical example are the integers with the ordering relation ≤ as we know it. Now, a poset is a structure where 4 doesn't hold, and a preorder is one where neither 3 nor 4 hold. Then what do these axioms mean, what do they do?

makes sure that every pair of elements is related. It excludes parallel structures and this axiom is what causes the set to collapse to a string. When Axiom 4 doesn't hold we may get a directed acyclic graph (DAG) instead. Well, sort of, as a directed acyclic graph does not necessarily imply transitivity, a poset does. More on transitivity below.
Given a total order (like the integers with ≤) we can degenerate it by adding 'parallel structure' (e.g. an element ε which is just like 3 but not identical to it).
suppresses cycles. It says that the only cycles are indentity arrows.

Given a total order (like the integers with ≤) we can create a cycle by adding a backward relation like (5≤2). Note that if axiom 3 / antisymmetry does not hold, axiom 4 cannot hold either, as the 'and' is incompatible with the 'either-or'.

What does the transitivity *axiom 2* do? That's a funny one. It implies associativity, and says that if you find two arrows that can be combined because their ends match, you're allowed to talk about the combined arrow. It actually says that the combined arrow has to be among our collected arrows.

You can break this structure by taking out a combined arrow, e.g. insisting that 2 and 4 cannot be compared, even though 2≤3 and 3≤4. Strike out the corresponding arrow, mark it red, you don't have enough gas to drive two routes...

As I said earlier, a poset is usually drawn as a DAG without outlining each and every matching combination of arrows. That's because people (and algorithms) have no trouble to understand that once we find a connected path between two points that those points are also connected. So people will often draw a DAG when they actually want to talk about posets.

message: The hard part, in my opinion, is the lack of standards. It is a pity. You prove something, but it will work only in coq, sometimes even with certain version, sometimes even worse with some certain version of coq and certain library of coq theorems. So basically if you spend a lot of time investing into coq, prooving theorems, at the end of the day it would be probably not exportable, and what is worse, tied to certain set of libraries, which means very particular base of logics.

I imagine it would be amazing if someone build this things in a shape it makes possible to exchange such proofs between various software tools, and even change logical base, for example expanding or consolidating definitions and axioms.
Yes, it's still early with these systems,
​​, in spite of their relatively long history.
Programming languages have life cycles. As the masses arrive, experimentation gets pushed down to a slower pace. People start
their code and an ecosystem begins to grow. Typically, we end up having lots of discussion on how to minimize maintenance (people upgrading their code) while being able to add new stuff to the base.

Sometimes a 'standard' grows out of very successful languages, meaning there's money for a commitee and many parties interested. I have no idea wether formal proofs can be encoded into a more static data format with the chance of surviving for a longer time. Or maybe there'll be popular notations you can then decode with a variety of systems.
It seems keeping mathematics alive is already challenging, maybe this is a chance to reorganize that process?

in my opinion it just contradict simple and stupid idea you can use programming approach instead of mathematics. Sometimes someone says that as Curry-Howard isomorphism is true, it is equivalent and it is all the story. But in fact it is very limited view of mathematical activity.
From one point of view, we have to went into this proof checkers tools method, and the reasons where discussed many times. Basically I am great fan of Voyevodsky ideas in this field.
But from the other side, at present it is as using assembly language for writing programs. It will simply doesn't work, even if you are able to write something what just works.

I suppose we should think about such things in a metamatatical ways: formal syntactic theory is just beginning. It may start with very basic syntactic rules, but we should build valuable mathematics at much higher level. Tools used in mathematical work should be much more universal, which here means independent of syntactic background. I don't know even if it is possible, because syntax is very precise set of rules. You can not have undefined syntax and use such tools. From the other side, certain syntactic systems are equivalent, so a lot of mathematics ( all if it?) is completely independent of one or another logical base used for syntactic firmal systems, as long as you working inside some pool of equivalent syntactic theories.

It reminds relation between group theory and representation group theory. A lot of comoutational software uses for example matrix representation, but there are tools  allowing various representations to be used, but independent of particular one.

​​​, programming languages, they're all Turing equivalent! And indeed, we see emulations to support legacy code, sometimes even more than one layer! Aside from the obvious cost of adding more code to it all, it also does not help the dwindling number of people able to read that code.

I think these organizational problems are independent of computer science (well, although perhaps practically intractable without machines to process the plenty of data this involves), and I have little doubt we'll see the same 'architectural' concepts apply, if we aren't already.

The formalization of programming languages (Chomsky hierarchy) yielded pretty computer language tools, and I'm certain we'll see more cool stuff help smooth out syntactical burden on the coder, and maybe even auto translate stuff into your context at some point. I have no idea how far it might take us.

However, what we have done in computer science seems to suggests that what we're doing with proof assistants right now, will improve over time. Even without new ideas! And maybe the plurality is unavoidable.

About a couple of years ago, I heard in a conference talk that about 20% of all papers at POPL, the highest impact conference in theoretical computer science, contain machine-checkable proofs. (Alas, I can't find the source any more - but it was a prestigious speaker.) This seems to suggest that tools like Coq might eventually trickle down.
It's Coq, not COQ.  That's all I know about this subject.
You mean it wasn't invented by Thierry COQuand?

! Yes, I see formal methods becoming more popular, but I don't have any numbers to quantify how fast it's happening. Many software engineers are trying hard to apply them to get code with fewer bugs. Security is just one reason why this has become very important, yet there's a very long way ahead! In other words, there's even more money, and many more people who'd want to use this stuff.
I wonder if formal methods will influence the way everybody interacts with technology. Often, disrupting technologies seem abstract and unnecessary for most areas of life, until they explode.
I have little hope that you will take on computers to do math with them anytime soon,
​​. But that's okay, I certainly don't think everybody has to, and your students seem perfectly capable to make their way,
​ and friend's Globular is just one example that is lots of fun and something everybody should try!

Also, not everything can be automated, and in my opinion mathematics is mostly about teaching and understanding, about communication! Maybe computers will help engineers to shoulder more results, and perhaps that means we'll have fewer students in higher maths in the end, but I can't imagine humanity to give up on this root of the most beautiful thing I can see mankind has come up with.

The animation below shows (greatly exaggerated) the effect of the gravitational waves from a binary neutron star on a spherical shell of free particles.  Think of the particles as lying at the vertices of the triangular grid; the grid itself is not meant to be any kind of physical object, but it has been drawn as a way to help illustrate the distances between the particles.  The shell is centred at the centre of the orbit, and is assumed to lie so far away from the neutron stars that we can completely neglect the tiny inwards tug from the inverse-square attraction, and concentrate on the waves alone.

Despite appearances, every point on this shell remains at the same distance from the centre, but it’s impossible to embed the warped geometry of the sphere in Euclidean space without distorting it this way.  But the varying distances between the points
faithfully represent how the wave would actually change them.

It’s not easy to judge the changing distances by eye, so I’ve coloured the edges between the points so that they grow redder when they are stretched and bluer when they are squeezed, compared to the original distances on the sphere in the absence of the waves.
To see the waves solely in the equatorial plane of the orbit, check out this previous post:
effects more clearly, try this applet:
(Changing the choice of “Angle between orbital plane and line of sight” in the applet takes the local view of the effects anywhere from the equatorial plane of the orbit to the pole above it.)

Embedding a sphere with this warped geometry is an example of what’s known as “the Weyl problem”:  given a two-dimensional manifold with the topology of a sphere and a metric whose Gaussian curvature is positive everywhere, can you embed the manifold isometrically in three-dimensional Euclidean space?  Luckily, the answer is yes, and the embedding is unique (up to an overall translation and rotation)!

A related problem, known as “the Minkowski problem”, asks for an embedding when you specify the Gaussian curvature at every point in the manifold, rather than the whole metric.  Both problems appear to have been solved in this 1953 paper by Louis Nirenberg:

Nirenberg gave an existence proof, but actually performing such an embedding can still be a tricky numerical problem.  In this case, I started with a perfect sphere and gradually deformed it, corresponding to the 1-parameter family of metrics you get as you dial-up the strength of the gravitational waves.
Nirenberg is a Canadian-American mathematician.  He was awarded the inaugural Chern Medal for “lifelong achievement” in 2010, and the Abel Prize, along with John Nash, in 2015.

The paper of Atiyah that really changed my life is

, which explained how TQFTs could be described as functors.  This led me to the Cobordism Hypothesis and now a general approach to open systems, where open systems of some particular sort are treated as morphisms in a category, and the "behavior" of open systems of this sort is described by a functor.  The basic idea here is called "functorial semantics" and was initiated by Lawvere in 1963.  After that it became important in the semantics of functional programming languages, but Atiyah introduced it in quantum physics, which gave it a whole new scope... and now I'm using it in electrical engineering, chemistry and the like.
It seems like I could stare at this one for a while. I'll keep it close!

Atiyah's been the mathematician whose work I've admired the most since I was a graduate student and learning about K-theory, Bott periodicity, and the Atiyah-Singer index theorem. The interaction of geometry and analysis in his work is profound and beautiful.

Michael Atiyah is fun to read, just look at the quote below the fold!
Here's another I just found on Wikiquote:

I always want to try to understand why things work. I’m not interested in getting a formula without knowing what it means. I always try to dig behind the scenes, so if I have a formula, I understand why it’s there. And understanding is a very difficult notion. People think mathematics begins when you write down a theorem followed by a proof. That’s not the beginning, that’s the end. For me the creative place in mathematics comes before you start to put things down on paper, before you try to write a formula. You picture various things, you turn them over in your mind. You’re trying to create, just as a musician is trying to create music, or a poet. There are no rules laid down. You have to do it your own way. But at the end, just as a composer has to put it down on paper, you have to write things down. But the most important stage is understanding. A proof by itself doesn’t give you understanding. You can have a long proof and no idea at the end of why it works. But to understand why it works, you have to have a kind of gut reaction to the thing. You’ve got to feel it.

claims to have proved the famous "abc conjecture" in number theory.  That's great!  There's just one problem: his proof is about 500 pages long, and almost nobody understands it, so mathematicians still can't tell if it's correct.
has just written a summary of the proof.  That's great!  There's just one problem: it's 294 pages long, and it seems very hard to understand.
I'm no expert on number theory, so my opinion doesn't really matter.  What's hard for
to understand may be easy for an expert!
But the most disturbing feature to me is that this new paper contains many theorems whose statements are
... with the proof being just "Follows from the definitions".
Of course, every true theorem follows from the definitions.  But the proof usually says how.
It's common to omit detailed proofs when one is summarizing someone else's work.  But even a sketchy argument would help us understand what's going on.

This is part of a strange pattern surrounding Mochizuki's work.  There was a conference in Oxford in 2015 aimed at helping expert number theorists understand it.   Many of them found it frustrating.   Brian Conrad wrote:

I don’t understand what caused the communication barrier that made it so difficult to answer questions in the final 2 days in a more illuminating manner. Certainly many of us had not read much in the papers before the meeting, but this does not explain the communication difficulties. Every time I would finally understand (as happened several times during the week) the intent of certain analogies or vague phrases that had previously mystified me (e.g., “dismantling scheme theory”), I still couldn’t see why those analogies and vague phrases were considered to be illuminating as written without being supplemented by more elaboration on the relevance to the context of the mathematical work.

At multiple times during the workshop we were shown lists of how many hours were invested by those who have already learned the theory and for how long person A has lectured on it to persons B and C. Such information shows admirable devotion and effort by those involved, but it is irrelevant to the evaluation and learning of mathematics. All of the arithmetic geometry experts in the audience have devoted countless hours to the study of difficult mathematical subjects, and I do not believe that any of us were ever guided or inspired by knowledge of hour-counts such as that. Nobody is convinced of the correctness of a proof by knowing how many hours have been devoted to explaining it to others; they are convinced by the force of ideas, not by the passage of time.
It's all very strange.  Maybe Mochizuki is just a lot smarter than than us, and we're like dogs trying to learn calculus.  Experts say he did a lot of brilliant work
his proof of the abc conjecture, so this is possible.
But, speaking as one dog to another, let me tell you what the
Looks simple, right?  Here a, b and c are positive integers that are
: they have no common factors except 1.   If we let d be the product of the distinct prime factors of abc, the conjecture says that d is usually not much smaller than c.
More precisely, it says that if p > 1, there are only finitely many choices of relatively prime a,b,c with a + b = c and

It looks obscure when you first see it.  It's famous because it has tons of consequences!   It implies the Fermat–Catalan conjecture, the Thue–Siegel–Roth theorem,  the Mordell conjecture, Vojta's conjecture (in dimension 1), the Erdős–Woods conjecture (except perhaps for a finitely many counterexamples)... blah blah blah... etcetera etcetera.
Let me just tell you the
, to give you a taste of this stuff.   In fact I'll just tell you one special case of that conjecture: there are at most finitely many solutions of

But the Fermat–Catalan conjecture has some fine print in it that rules out certain choices of these exponents.  In fact, if we rule out those exponents and also certain silly choices of x,y,z, it says there are only finitely many solutions even if we let the exponents vary! By combining a relative anabelian result (relative Grothendieck Conjecture over sub-p-adic felds (Theorem B.1)) and "hidden endomorphism" diagram (EllCusp) (resp. "hidden endomorphism" diagram (BelyiCusp)), we show absolute anabelian results: the elliptic cuspidalisation (Theorem 3.7) (resp. Belyi cuspidalisation (Theorem 3.8)). By using Belyi cuspidalisations, we obtain an absolute mono-anabelian reconstruction of the NF-portion of the base field and the function field (resp. the base field) of hyperbolic curves of strictly Belyi type over sub-p-adic fields (Theorem 3.17) (resp. over mixed characteristic local fields (Corollary 3.19)). This gives us the philosophy of arithmetical holomorphicity and mono-analyticity (Section 3.5), and the theory of Kummer isomorphism from Frobenius-like objects to etale-like objects (cf. mathematicians say – to the scary theorems that crawl out of their caves around page 200!

He is the leader of and the main contributor to one of major parts of modern number theory: anabelian geometry. His contributions include his famous solution of the Grothendieck conjecture in anabelian geometry about hyperbolic curves over number fields. He initiated and developed several other fundamental developments: absolute anabelian geometry, mono-anabelian geometry, and combinatorial anabelian geometry. Among other theories, Mochizuki introduced and developed Hodge–Arakelov theory, p-adic Teichmüller theory, the theory of frobenioids, and the etale theta-function theory.

This is part of a strange pattern surrounding Mochizuki's work.  There was a conference in Oxford in 2015 aimed at helping expert number theorists understand it.   Many of them found it frustrating.   Brian Conrad wrote:

I don’t understand what caused the communication barrier that made it so difficult to answer questions in the final 2 days in a more illuminating manner. Certainly many of us had not read much in the papers before the meeting, but this does not explain the communication difficulties. Every time I would finally understand (as happened several times during the week) the intent of certain analogies or vague phrases that had previously mystified me (e.g., “dismantling scheme theory”), I still couldn’t see why those analogies and vague phrases were considered to be illuminating as written without being supplemented by more elaboration on the relevance to the context of the mathematical work.

At multiple times during the workshop we were shown lists of how many hours were invested by those who have already learned the theory and for how long person A has lectured on it to persons B and C. Such information shows admirable devotion and effort by those involved, but it is irrelevant to the evaluation and learning of mathematics. All of the arithmetic geometry experts in the audience have devoted countless hours to the study of difficult mathematical subjects, and I do not believe that any of us were ever guided or inspired by knowledge of hour-counts such as that. Nobody is convinced of the correctness of a proof by knowing how many hours have been devoted to explaining it to others; they are convinced by the force of ideas, not by the passage of time.
It's all very strange.  Maybe Mochizuki is just a lot smarter than than us, and we're like dogs trying to learn calculus.  Experts say he did a lot of brilliant work
his proof of the abc conjecture, so this is possible.

On my way home yesterday I ran into

Renormalization isn't a weird and ill-founded grab-bag of ideas, at least not anymore. Back in the seventies(!) Eppstein and Glaser created a solid foundation, eliminating the need for a cut-off with a few insights and by then working it all through in a very tidy way.

In essence they realized that to keep the distributions well behaved, they needed to make sure that they would stay inside the domain for the maps on the next level. Being more careful with the Dirac delta at zero, or rather picking enough derivatives for it in the right way would do the trick.
Or so, I know next to noting about these things! I took notes:
Epstein and Glaser (70's) search for 'microlocal analysis'.
There should be a nice book by Günter Scharf, I haven't looked for yet...

The other bit, and I just realize I had been told before: Gravitation is renormalizable in a straight-forward way. It's just that you'd have to pick an infinite number of parameters, derivatives of a delta function as above.

As I happen to have been reading about spinors recently we had them as a nice starter for a short walk, getting us to recall the emotions that accompany a sudden widening in perspective, perhaps after an intense period of work, and how it has been described historically. Episodes of uncontrollable giggling anyone?

The magic (the neat mathematics) happens in section 3.2 there. In equation (3.2.46) it is discovered that all the "renormalization freedom" is encoded in the coefficients of a distribution with point support, hence in derivatives of a delta distribution, at the point where the particle interaction happens.  Getting this step mathematically wrong (by not handling distributions properly) is what  leads to the notorious "infinitities" in other approaches. The other, more popular option is the Ken Wilson approach, in which you admit really explicitly that you're using an effective theory with a cutoff. In effective field theory it's not considered particularly upsetting to end up with a theory with an infinite number of parameters; they're suppressed by larger and larger powers of the cutoff, and if you make an admittedly additional assumption that the dimensionless parameters don't blow up correspondingly, you can do calculations with the first few terms.

From this perspective, gravity's "non-renormalizability" doesn't really mean you can't renormalize it, it just means there's nothing but suppressed terms. That is, gravity should be a weak force at mundane energies. And so it is.

The approach came out of condensed-matter physics, in which you can model some phenomena as continuum field theories but you know you're really dealing with a bunch of atoms, so the atomic scale is a natural short-distance cutoff.
But, on the other hand, it's awfully nice if you actually
get a well-behaved theory (or at least a better-behaved one) on a smooth manifold. And that's apparently what Scharf was doing.
I get that, generally, continuous functions are the approximation to the world, not the other way around! We use infinite series
they are simpler than the cascading complexities we find in nature.
And that's why I'd expect the idealization, the mathematical tool, to be more tame than the data it aims to model. That's precisely why I found the idea of a cut-off unsettling!

Someone must have made a dictionary of analogies between groups and rings.  It's worth noting that there's also process that turns any group into a ring, which preserves most of these analogies.
But the dictionary I like is called

algebraic structures, of which groups, rings, Lie algebras, etc. are examples.  This was developed to a certain rather high level by Garrett Birkhoff, summarized in the Wikipedia article here, but later pushed much further using category theory, especially by Bill Lawvere.

For any sort of algebraic structure we have concepts like 'homomorphism', 'direct sum' (or in more modern language 'coproduct'), 'subobject', modding out to get a 'quotient object', etc., obeying a bunch of familiar rules.
Universal algebra explains how all these concepts work in general.

For algebraic structures that have a sufficiently well-behaved 'zero' element, like groups and rings, we can define teh 'kernel' of a homomorphism, and we can form a quotient object by formally setting some elements equal to zero.

However, these examples are misleading!  In general the right way to form a quotient object is to mod out by an equivalence relation that gets along with all the operations: a so-called 'congruence relation'.  This approach works more generally.

The reason why subrings don't work for quotienting, but ideals do, is that subrings don't allow for a well-defined multiplication. Let R be a ring, and S a subring. Then two elements r and t of R are equal modulo S, that is, r + S = t + S iff r = t + s for some s in S. Now let's define multiplication by (r + S) x (t + S) = (r x t) + S. For this to be well defined, we need: if r1 + S = t1 + S and r2 + S = t2 +S, then r1 x r2 + S = t1 x t2 + S. From the assumption we get r1 = t1 + s1 and r2 = t1 + s2 for some s1, s2 in S. So we need that r1 x r2 = t1 x t2 + s for some s in S. But r1 x r2 = (t1 + s1) x (t2 + s2) = t1 x t2 + t1 x s2 + s1 x t2 + s1 x s2. While s1 x s2 is indeed in S, we have now guarantee that t1 x s2 and s1 x t2 are in S. But if S where an ideal, it would be closed against multiplication with
ring elements, so t1 x s2 and t2 x s1 would be in S, and multiplication would be well defined. This shows why we need ideals.

C*-algebras do not form a variety in the sense of universal algebra.  The reason is that C*-algebras, unlike groups and rings, are not defined just by listing operations on some set and identities that the operations obey.  The norm of an element is not again an element!  More importantly, the norm obeys an inequality.
So, Birkhoff's HSP theorem says the category of C*-algebras must lack some nice properties.
But star-rings form a variety, and they're a very nice generalization of C*-algebras.  See the link, which is actually a definition of star-ring, despite its appearance.

Interesting. I first read about "universal algebra"  around 2007 and I was intrigued by the "universal" part of the name.  Some decades before in my freshmen physics studies we had a course called simply 'algebra". What we saw there was exactly that: structures build on sets by defining the appropriate type of operations and mapping (aka morphism), using it to partition the domain (the modding) and to define the canonical decomposition of that mapping. Of course each type of structures has its own particular properties worth studying but the way to talk about them was the same: start with sets and functions between them, where each function defines an equivalence relation induced by the equality of the images. This gives rise to a canonical projection from the domain onto the quotient set. The decomposition of the function through it follows  immediately. From this point on introduce internal binary operations on a set and proceed analogously. Here it seemed natural to talk about morphisms otherwise one loses all the extra information introduced by the internal operation. In this way we would build monoids, groups, rings, fields, and vectorial spaces. It was fun.

The E8 lattice (or Gosset lattice) is a very regular lattice in 8 dimensions (it is generated by the E8 root system, and realizes the optimal sphere packing in 8 dimensions). The Voronoi cell of a lattice point is the set of points closer to that lattice point than to any other: the Voronoi cells of the E8 lattice are polytopes with 240 facets and 19440 vertices (of two kinds, 2160 corresponding to the "deep" holes of E8 and 17280 to the "shallow" holes), and the Voronoi diagram of E8 is the tiling of 8-space by these polytopes.

This video shows a three-dimensional cross-section of the Voronoi diagram of E8, with two dimensions displayed as image coordinates and the third dimension as time (i.e., each frame is a two-dimensional cross-section, and this section is translated uniformly in time, perpendicularly to its plane, in a random direction).

The plane direction in this video has been chosen to be a symmetry plane of order 24 for the lattice, which explains the 24-fold symmetry which occurs exactly around a lattice point and approximately in various places.

A lattice point (which we can call "origin") is encountered exactly in the middle of the video, at the center of the screen. So at this point, an exact 24-fold symmetry is encountered. (Of course, everything is symmetric around this point.)

SU(3), the group of unitary 3 × 3 matrices with determinant 1, isn’t an easy thing to visualise as a space.  It  is an 8-dimensional manifold that sits in 18-dimensional Euclidean space, which is a few too many dimensions to keep track of in the mind’s eye.

But we can project it down to something a bit more manageable.  For a start, every matrix in SU(3) can be diagonalised, and the result will always be a matrix whose three diagonal elements are complex numbers of absolute value 1, and whose product is 1.  So this

will be topologically the same as the surface of a doughnut, with the phase angles of just two of the diagonal elements enough to fully specify a point in the space.  The phase angle of the third element is always the opposite of the sum of the other two phase angles, in order that the product of all three diagonal elements is 1.
This 2-dimensional torus is embedded in a 6-dimensional Euclidean space, but we can project it down to the complex plane by adding up all three complex numbers.  That is, we take the
of each matrix.  And since the trace is unchanged by the process of diagonalising a matrix, this projection will actually show us the traces of all the matrices in SU(3) itself.
In 2012, there was a nice discussion on
's Azimuth blog about the fact that the traces of all the elements of SU(3) lie in a
in the complex plane, which generalises to the traces of all the elements of SU(N) lying in a hypocycloid with N cusps:
But somehow I never quite got a sense of how the torus that is the diagonal subgroup of SU(3) projected down to a deltoid.  The animation below is an attempt to visualise this.

First, the torus is generated in a topologically correct but geometrically simplified form, by taking a circle that represents the first phase and sweeping it around with the second phase, while pretending that the third diagonal element is zero.  When complete, this is a Clifford torus, which lies on the surface of a sphere in 4-dimensional Euclidean space.
Then, the torus morphs to its correct geometry, which protrudes into all 6 dimensions, by bringing the size of the third element up to its full value of 1.

Suppose you take the lattice Z^4, which consists of all points in four-dimensional Euclidean space with integer coordinates, and place a sphere at every point in the lattice, of just the right size so that every sphere touches exactly eight neighbours.

Can we choose an angular velocity for each sphere such that their linear velocities all match at the points of contact?  There’s actually an infinite-dimensional space of solutions, but for the lattice Z^n there’s a particularly nice finite-dimensional solution space, of dimension  ½n(n–1):
M(x) = the sum over all j < k of (–1)^(x_j + x_k) a_{j, k} e_j ∧ e_k
Here a_{j, k} are just ½n(n–1) parameters that single out a particular solution, e_j and e_k are basis vectors in R^n, and e_j ∧ e_k is the

It’s not hard to check that, for two neighbouring points whose coordinates differ by ±1 in the
which is exactly the condition we need for the linear velocities of the two neighbouring spheres at their point of contact to be equal.

Now, for n=4 we have a 6-parameter space of solutions, but in general these solutions will not give each sphere a single, well-defined rotational period.  That is to say, if we note the location of every point on one sphere at time zero, and then let it rotate with the angular velocity M(x) for some arbitrary choice of a_{1,2} ... a_{3,4}, there might

come a time when every point is back where it started.  A generic angular velocity in four dimensions has two separate periods, associated with two orthogonal planes, and unless they are rational multiples of each other the sphere will never return to its initial configuration.
One way to guarantee a well-defined rotational period is to limit ourselves to the subspace:

These conditions make the matrices M(x) for each sphere in the lattice alternately self-dual and anti-self-dual: that is, the act of swapping angular velocities in any of the coordinate planes for those in the orthogonal plane either leaves M unchanged, or simply inverts its sign.

For this 3-parameter family of solutions, the rotations of each sphere carry the eight contact points around four distinct, non-intersecting great circles, and these circles are coplanar with the ones on neighbouring spheres that they touch. So it’s possible to set up structures along these circles that mesh at the contact points in much the same manner as flat gears.

The image below shows a portion of a Z^4 lattice (a 3 × 3 × 3 cube, with one dimension fixed) with a_{1, 2} = a_{1, 3} = a_{1, 4} = 1. The structures are projected down to three dimensions but given hues that vary according to the omitted fourth coordinate. Each sphere has four circular “gears” wrapped around it, but some of these project to straight line segments rather than circles or ellipses.

video about complements of knots and links many times over the years.  My dad actually brought it home one day when I was in high school in the mid-90s, at which point it seemed so "out there" that a friend and I found it comical.  Given that beginning, it's funny how much I've come to connect with it.
I revisited it again this weekend.  I figured attempting to draw the video's finale image myself would lead to fun insights, and the exercise did not disappoint.  So here is a pannable image of what
calls the "hyperbolic structure of the link complement" for the Borromean rings.
It's a honeycomb of rhombic dodecahedra, each with 6 ideal vertices and 8 finite vertices.  If you stare out it for a bit, you will notice
, i.e. a set of 3 mutually orthogonal axes.  These triplets of infinitely long lines connect up with each other at the ideal points to build up the entire 1-skeleton of the honeycomb.

Note how we could fit even more ortho-sticks into this structure.  An additional ortho-stick would fit inside each rhombic dodecahedron to connect up the 6 ideal vertices, each line connecting two antipodes.
Here was my approach to making this image.  A rhombic dodecahedron is a

, i.e. a dual to a uniform solid, so I thought the honeycomb might be dual to one of the uniform honeycombs, which I knew how to draw.  Catalan solids share the same symmetry group as their duals, so I went looking in the Wikipedia list (link below) for the right reflection group, and suspected {3,4,4} was it.  If so, it would just be a matter of finding the right starting edge(s) in the fundamental simplex to reflect around.

I knew the edges would have one ideal point (only one choice in the simplex for this) and one finite point.  I also knew the finite point was at the intersection of these ortho-sticks, which determined it.  (The simplex is what is called an
, and just one point of the simplex would yield ortho-sticks.)  Both points are vertices of the fundamental simplex.

However, the resulting 1-skeleton wasn't quite right.  It had too many edges and wasn't a well-formed honeycomb - faces would have been skew.  The extra edges are precisely the ortho-sticks I described adding to the interior of rhombic dodecahedra above.  An "alternation-like" operation to remove ortho-sticks having an odd number of reflections across one of the mirror planes did the trick.
So this is not a "Catalan" honeycomb as suspected, but is tied up with the symmetry group.  It is
the dual of the rectified {4,4,3}.  Thurston was one of the creators of
, and he also discusses the Borromean rings in his book

.  There, he says the hyperbolic structure of the link complement can be built from two ideal octahedra.  Well, the simplest honeycomb of the {3,4,4} reflection group is composed of ideal octahedra, further reinforcing that connection.
One last observation.  Isn't it strange how some of the ideal vertices appear closer than some of the finite ones?

It is with the deepest regret that I announce the passing of Solomon (Sol) W. Golomb. Few mathematicians have the intelligence and foresight to create a new area of mathematics and Sol was one of them. His book “Polyominoes,” first published in 1965, codified an entire field of recreational mathematics and Sol invented the term “polyomino” in 1953. While a few problems involving polyominoes had appeared earlier, he was the one that made it a discipline.

A polyomino is a plane geometric figure formed by putting one or more square figures of the same size together by the edges. Polyominoes of any number of squares can be created, although the smaller structures are the most easy to work with. The number of polyominoes that can be created using n squares grows rapidly. There are 12 that can be made with 5 squares, 63,600 with 12 squares and approximately 7 x 10^31 with 56 squares. Therefore, the number of problems is effectively infinite. Sol’s series of papers that appeared in “Recreational Mathematics Magazine” in 1961-1963 are classic papers that introduced and expanded the field.

The most famous polyominoes are the pentominoes, the twelve figures that can be made with five squares. This term was also invented by Sol and many pentomino problems appeared in “Journal of Recreational Mathematics” over the years it was published. I got my start in writing extensive programs to solve recreational mathematics problems by creating programs to solve problems involving constructions using the two and three-dimensional pentominoes.

One of the beauties of the polyominoes is that no higher mathematical ability is needed to work with them. Basic problems can be given to elementary children and they can be created for any level of difficulty and the polyominoes are inexpensive to produce. I once reviewed a kit of pentomino problems designed for elementary school children to aid them in developing spatial orientation skills.

Sol is now gone but he left a legacy of mathematics that can be used to educate and entertain. I encourage all people with an interest in math to acquire and read one of the editions of “Polyominoes.” It is an addictive area of mathematics that can be read and understood by everyone.

The most famous polyominoes are the pentominoes, the twelve figures that can be made with five squares. This term was also invented by Sol and many pentomino problems appeared in “Journal of Recreational Mathematics” over the years it was published. I got my start in writing extensive programs to solve recreational mathematics problems by creating programs to solve problems involving constructions using the two and three-dimensional pentominoes.

One of the beauties of the polyominoes is that no higher mathematical ability is needed to work with them. Basic problems can be given to elementary children and they can be created for any level of difficulty and the polyominoes are inexpensive to produce. I once reviewed a kit of pentomino problems designed for elementary school children to aid them in developing spatial orientation skills.

Sol is now gone but he left a legacy of mathematics that can be used to educate and entertain. I encourage all people with an interest in math to acquire and read one of the editions of “Polyominoes.” It is an addictive area of mathematics that can be read and understood by everyone.

What shape is this 'forbidden region', and why?

The other table is a rectangle with rounded ends, called the
.   For that one the billiards move chaotically.  After a while they seem randomized.
This illustrates two very different kinds of dynamical systems.  The 'completely integrable' systems, like the elliptical billiards, do very predictable things.   The 'ergodic' ones seem random.
With some math, we can make these ideas precise.  I'll be quick: a system whose motion is described by Hamiltonian mechanics is
if it has the maximum number of conserved quantities.   It's
if it has the minimum number.   All sorts of in-between cases are also possible!

Descending sequences are what makes the names of ordinals finite. That's a very useful idea! Let me elaborate a bit:
Omega is the limit of all natural numbers, yet it doesn't contain any infinite number. While omega itself can be considered infinite, it is just a single one, so a single symbol "w" suffices.

While it is true that w^w contains a name for polynomials with as many variables you like, every one of them is finite. Formally, if you pick any countable ordinal there's an addressing scheme providing finite names for it and all the ones below.
This is captured by the idea of descending sequences. To descend from omega we have to pick a finite number. There are infinitely many to pick from, but any one is finite.

- While your boss might find that to be a troubling attitude, your logician friends will be there to recognize your achievement for what it really is: In this case, a cool illustration of how the uncomputability of the busy beaver escalates for increasing arguments.

To compute the busy beaver function B(n) you first need to know which of all the Turing machines with n or fewer states do halt, and which don't. Of those that terminate, B measures the maximum possible runtime.

If you can't even show wether a particular program of size n halts (e.g. using the popular ZFC axioms), then you can't know the value of B(n) (if ZFC is all you believe in). Since we do know that ZFC cannot prove that it never leads to a contradiction, this then encompasses what we can say about our program, been tailored to search for such a contradiction or never halt.
What we're witnessing here is people lowering the bar from where onward we can be sure that B is at least as weird as that.

What do you think, can it be done in fewer steps? Share your guess in the comment section! My bet is that it can't be done in fewer than 1001 states. Or rather that we won't witness the bound pushed below 1002 before 2017.

Guessing this is incredibly hard, because there may be some (yet unknown) result from number theory telling us solving a simpler problem would be equivalent, thus allowing to drastically reduce the bound further. Just give it a try!

Is AlphaGo planning to kill everybody?
Here's what I think is hard for AlphaGo, and I don't expect that to be solved anytime soon (not within the next few years).

The machine has some kind of intuition, it's great in spotting highly promising moves. They also taught it to splendor in endgame situations, it's good at solving cominatorial problems with only a 'few' possible moves to consider.
What I think it cannot do is to combine these techniques, to come up with a sinister plan as a human player might.
I think that's because the combinatorial solver needs a clear signal, a small set of possibilities to try.

The guessing part, on the other hand, seems to know quite well how to avoid disadvantageous situations, but it cannot see dangers that are too improbable to be part of its gut knowledge, that lie beyond its horizon.

Some people said that the machine might have problems with too much aji (potential) and I'd say that fits well. I think it may take a grandmaster to set up such a position - while enduring AlphaGo's assaults in the meantime.
[Eternal gameplay would be completely incomprehensible to us]﻿

An easier way to say the idea of the Yoneda theorem is that you can recover an object x up to isomorphism if you know hom(x,y) for every object y - or more precisely, if you know the functor
So, you know an object x if you know all the morphisms out of it to other objects, and how composing a morphism to y with a morphism from y to z gives a morphism to z.
So, more vaguely, you know a thing if you know all its relationships to other things.
The Yoneda embedding theorem goes deeper, but I've always found this to be the easy way in.
Yes, x is encoded into hom(x, -).
For an example, pick your favorite category, and your favorite object x in that category.

You want to formulate your theory such that it is most general. It should describe as much as possible of the structure it intends to emphasize.
One should also do it in the simplest possible way. And there's the choice: Make an exception excluding zero from the domain, or concoct an ad-hoc rule assigning it a value that fits the structure.
Modern mathematicians seem to prefer the latter, seeing theorems as independent of philosophy and interpretation.

From a young age you learn how to work with collections of objects, starting with collections whose sizes are small naturals. But you don't learn how to work with zero sized collections until much later. It seems like it's actually a pretty advanced subject. People with a strong scientific training, say, sometimes have a hard time with zero-sized collections even though they should be easier to work with than the size one, two and three sets they've been using since infancy. After all they have fewer elements.
For example: how many sequences of binary digits of length zero are there? It seems obvious to me that there's exactly one. But some people think this is an arbitrary stretch of the word
and that you could just as easily say there aren't any such sequences.

Or how many ways are there to arrange zero people in pairs? Again, I think it's obvious that there is one way to form pairs from no people. But many think it's clear that if there are no people, there's no way of forming pairs.
1. Is there a zero sized increasing subsequence of (1, 2, 3, ..., 9)?
2. Or a zero sized subset of {1,2,..100} the product of whose elements is odd?
3. Or a zero sized subset of {2,...100} of pairwise coprime elements?
4. Does the vector space with one element have a basis?

I think there's a clear answer in each case. This is, of course, an issue of semantics. But I think in each case there is a natural choice of meaning for the words that makes calculations consistent with non-zero sized sets. But maybe you disagree. And maybe this subject should be taught as part of at least one course so that everyone can agree on what exactly their words mean for zero-sized sets.
I guess it doesn't help that mathematicians don't even agree on whether zero is a natural :-)

How does a physicist rationalize the fact that all her/his life's work may turn out to be meaningless?

A physicist may chase a particular theory/phenomenon all his life solely because he is in love with the subject. However, knowing the history of science, his work may get trashed anytime. How does a physicist still motivate oneself?
There are many answers to your question.

: the belief that one is likely to succeed where others have failed.  It's widespread, but I suspect it's even more common among people who work on high-risk projects - like trying to market a new invention, or trying to figure out new fundamental laws of physics.   People who are not optimistic are unlikely to succeed in physics.

Another answer: it's easy to keep thinking one will succeed in theoretical physics, compared to business, because there are few definitive signs of failure except for making an experimental prediction and having it fail when tested.  You'll notice that string theory and loop quantum gravity, two popular theories of physics, make no definitive testable predictions at this time.  That is, there's no experiment we could do now that would definitively disprove these theories.  So, no matter what experiments are done, people can continue to work on these theories and feel their work will succeed someday.

Furthermore, physics can lead to interesting and important mathematics even if it's wrong or untestable by experiment!  String theory, in particular, has been incredibly successful as a source of mathematical ideas.  So, if one is content with that, one can remain happy.

Finally, if one loves doing something and manages to get paid to do it, it's hard to stop.  And as one grows up and matures, one may realize that there's more to life than succeeding in an ambitious dream.   If one has the opportunity to be part of a noble tradition, if one has the opportunity to teach students to continue this tradition, one should consider oneself lucky.

All our lives are meaningless - there is no point searching for meaning in physics, or science. That we learn pretty quickly. The question is: can you live without searching for patterns, for structure, for some sort of 'logic' to it all, even knowing full well you will probably never find anything fascinating? Are you able to watch nature, hear about physics (say QM or GR) or other sciences, and just "let it be"? Or do you need to find out more, even just a little, or just be part of the process? I can understand both answers to this well enough - yes, curiosity killed the cat, and no, I do not know any compelling reason not to just let it all go and live a life dedicated to unbridled hedonism. But for some people, for some period of time, the scientific process may become part of almost-sensual pleasures... sometimes the tiny break-throughs, the instants you finally understand something that you had so far totally missed... it can almost make the other decades of your wasted life seem worthwhile. But sometimes, most times, it slips away, it's no pleasure anymore, just boring sisyphean drudgery, and that is when one has to wonder...

Having said that, I think teaching can be a life-line - hand over the responsibility for anything worthwhile to the next generation. At least one can be a part of "culture", of the transmission of ignorance to the new guys: face it, they won't find anything that much more fascinating to waste their 80 years on either, so you're handing them excellent occupational therapy.

Here's a reason for you for why you'd want listen to mathematicians and it's up to you to form an opinion.

One sometimes hears political activists complain of "suspiciously convenient timing" when media coverage of an important and controversial event related to their cause is drowned out by some unrelated news event dominating the headlines.  For instance, in domestic US politics, there were suspicions raised recently in some quarters that the various votes to give fast-track authority to the US president to negotiate the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement were deliberately timed to coincide with other headline-grabbing events, such as the multiple shootings in Charleston, or the recent significant Supreme Court decisions on the Affordable Care Act and marriage equality.

But actually, the laws of probability predict such "convenient" coincidences to occur with a surprisingly high frequency, even in the absence of any conspiracy to co-ordinate timing (for reasons similar to those behind the birthday paradox, linked below).  To oversimplify things slightly, if
* a controversial event that the authorities would prefer not to draw attention to occurs every X days on average; and
* a spectacular event dominating the headlines occurs every Y days on average;
then just from random chance, we would have
* a coincidence in which a controversial event conveniently occurs on the same day as a spectacular event will occur every XY days on average.
The frequency of such coincidences also rapidly increases if one widens the window defining such a coincidence, for instance
* a controversial event will occur within a day of a spectacular event every XY/3 days on average;
* a controversial event will occur on the same week of a spectacular event every XY/7 days on average;

For instance, in this month of June in domestic US media, "controversial" events included two votes for TPP and one vote to reauthorise the Patriot act, while "spectacular" events included the Charleston shooting, two major Supreme Court decisions, a celebrity very publicly becoming transgender, and an extensively covered prison break, among others.  This suggests values of X and Y comparable to 10 and 5 respectively,  so that same-day coincidences should be expected about once every two months, and within-a-day coincidences once every two to three weeks.  This is admittedly a very back-of-the-envelope calculation involving a fairly short time interval of analysis and a rather subjective interpretation of what is "controversial" or "spectacular", but I expect these numbers to be of about the right order of magnitude.

One could in principle try to set up a more careful test to see if there is a statistically significant correlation between the timing of "controversial" and "spectacular" events, though given human nature I would expect that a negative result for such a test would do little to change the minds of someone who sees such a coincidence and is convinced that it is not purely due to chance.

EDIT: the same analysis suggests that a day with two or more spectacular events should occur about once every 2Y^2 days, on the average.  It seems that today could be one of these days, at least as far as the US media is concerned.

Yeah, I've seen many of those efforts at generalization, and I understand the criticisms as an artistic debate with perceptions that we mostly can share about the exhibited variants.

To justify an own generic criticism with how 3D is investigated - I feel it's excessively condescending to the particular harmony of 2D with conformal geometry that's at the heart of the M-set, and trying to effect the shift from 2D to 3D in ways that neglect that special harmony, like we do or would in contexts where it isn't at play.

In my previous comment, I argued for a shift to 3D where, indeed, the usual 2D Mandelset isn't a slice of the 3D object, but instead we'd have a 3D labyrinthine object such that all the views we are familiar with of the 2D set are optical projections of the 3D set, and such that smaller details in fact correspond to features at greater optical distance of the camera. Imagine the Mandelbrot Set as the face of an Universe on a celestial sphere. Zooming in on smaller features transforms to zooming in on equally-sized features but more distant.

I got drawn into learning physics again. This time, it was the
. That's a swinging system that is driven by some activity that is periodically repeated. But

by an external force like a parent pushing a swing with a child. Rather, by changing the swinging system itself, like a child squatting and standing on a swing. The difference matters. For example, a pushing parent can make move a swing that's initially at rest. A child that squats and stands can't: the swing must have some inital energy, however tiny, which is then amplified by the standing and squatting!

In physics, there are important parametric oscillators where the "stand and squat" frequency differs from the "natural" frequency of the oscillator. Like a weird child that doesn't care when the swing has reached the apex. A popular case is where the driving consists of adding to the "natural" frequency a cosine of some other frequency. That case is called the "Mathieu equation".

when the peak amplitude keeps on increasing forever. Whether that happens depends on a certain pair eigenvalues that go along with the parametric oscillator. Those eigenvalues are two complex numbers satisfying two conditions: Their product is one, and they are complex conjugates of one another. In particular, they are either both on the complex unit circle, or reciprocal reals. In the latter case, we have resonance. The eigenvalue with the larger absolute value describes the rate at which the amplitude grows.

The image shows the eigenvalues for a Mathieu equation. The frequency of the cosine increases along the vertical axis. The horizontal plane represents the complex plane. It contains both eigenvalues. When we look at the bunny from the top, we see (1) a circle: the complex unit circle, plus (2) some perpendicular lines sticking out at opposite sides: the "face" and "tail(s)" of the bunny. That matches our above observation about the possible eigenvalues. The face of the bunny is the biggest resonance. It occurs where the frequency of the cosine is about twice that of the natural frequency. Another resonance is the (topmost) tail. It occurs where the frequency of the cosine is about the same as the natural frequency. The "tails" further below correspond to more resonances at lower cosine frequencies.
I wrote a blog article about this that contains all the maths, including proofs:
. I managed to shed some light on an issue which I didn't find in the literature: the precise mathematical situation at the

in and out of resonance. That is, the points where the bunny's head and tail is attached to the body. For the ambitious and under-occupied, I even left a mathematical conjecture at the end of the blog post: a conjecture about which "monodromies" are realizable by parametric oscillators. If you have a proof for the conjecture, please let me know!

Are these waves going to the left or the right?
The big pulses are moving to the right.  The
is the velocity of the big pulses, so this is positive.
The little wiggles are moving to the left.   The
is the velocity of these little wiggles, so this is negative.

So, the group velocity and phase velocity can be completely different!   You have to be careful when you talk about the speed of waves.  Indeed, if this wave was a rope wiggling up and down, the rope itself wouldn't be going left
right!   The speed of the wave is an abstraction... and we can define it in different ways.
There's also the signal velocity.  Say you start with no wave at all to the right of some point.  How far to the right of that point can the wave get in one second?  That's the

than this!  That doesn't violate any laws of physics.

Allen's well written post gets you all the details and how the idea was found. I guess no one has tried to print it, yet. You might be the first!
features 55 cards, each bearing 8 symbols, such that any two cards have a unique symbol in common. The first person to call out the symbol wins the two cards. (There are several variations.)

Imagine that instead of a symbol (cheese, igloo, clover, stop sign, ...) we have a line through the origin in 3-space. If that's too big to think about then intersect it with the unit sphere, getting two antipodal points. And instead of a card full of symbols, think of a plane through the origin in 3-space, containing all its lines. Again, you can instead picture a great circle on the unit sphere. Now you find that any two planes intersect in a unique line, or more compactly, any two great circles intersect in a unique antipodal pair of points.

That might seem a bit too infinite to describe this game. The trick is to work in 3-space with coordinates that aren't real numbers, but instead are in the integers mod p. (Let's take p a prime to avoid nastiness.) Which p?
Each line contains p-1 nonzero vectors. A plane contains p^2-1. So a plane contains (p^2-1)/(p-1) = p+1 lines. Here that's 8, so p=7.
The total number of lines (and planes) should be (p^3-1)/(p-1) = p^2 + p + 1, which here would be 57. Warning: hereafter I'm going to refer to these lines and planes as
I heard that there's only 55 because they couldn't quite fit 57 on the sheet of paper they cut to make the game. Oops.

is sometimes unwinnable. In that game (not included in the rules -- a bonus for reading this post!) you call out two symbols, and look for the unique card that contains both. Hours later, you learn that you picked one of the two impossible pairs.
I had a lengthy dream last night asking

about how the game should change if one adds cards corresponding to conics in the projective plane. Since F_7 isn't algebraically closed, I don't imagine all the conics are isomorphic, or even have F_7-points. So we should only use conics that actually have eight F_7-points.
(I don't know.) Of course it'll be hard to tell them apart from the old, degree 1, cards, so maybe we can give them a yellow border or something.

In the antipode-and-great-circle picture, imagine intersecting the unit sphere with a cone like x^2 + 2y^2 = z^2, giving two antipodal ellipses. If you slice that with a great circle, you can get two antipodal pairs, not just one.
Now how does the game work? Pull up two cards, and announce
the points of intersection between the two. By Bézout's theorem there should be 1, 2, 4 depending on whether you're looking at 0, 1, 2 conics. But this is only when they are counted

. So there will be the very occasional, but maddening, occurrence that you get a line card and conic card that only have one symbol in common, corresponding to the great circle and antipodal ellipses being tangent.

There's a worse problem, though -- maybe the points of intersection are only defined over a field extension of F_7! (Jordan didn't catch me on that in the dream; for shame.) So some sort of compatibility must hold between the line and conic for there to be a point at all. How should we label the cards to indicate this? Jordan?

Maybe the thing to do is work over a smaller field like F_3, so only have cards corresponding to the projective lines and conics that are defined over F_3, but have the cards labeled with all the F_9-points. Then any two of these lines and conics should have an F_9-point in common.

of a convex n-gon is a way to divide the n-gon into non-overlapping triangles in such a way that the corners of each triangle are three of the corners of the original n-gon. For example, the picture shows a triangulation of a heptagon (or 7-gon) which, inevitably, consists of 7–2 = 5 triangles.

of a Coxeter–Conway frieze is the number of rows in the frieze excluding the top and bottom rows of 1s; for example, the frieze in the picture has width 4. Conway and Coxeter proved that, for a fixed n, there is a one to one correspondence between Coxeter–Conway friezes of width n–3 on the one hand, and triangulations of a convex n-gon on the other hand.

To see how this works, let us look at the seven corners of the heptagon, working clockwise from the lowest corner shown. The number of triangles meeting at each of the seven corners is 2, 2, 1, 4, 2, 1, 3. These are exactly the entries of the second to top row of the frieze! The same idea can be used to match every frieze of width 4 with a triangulation of a heptagon, and vice versa. It follows from this result that the entries in any given row of a frieze of width n–3 must form a periodic cycle of length 7, and indeed this is the case for the frieze in the picture.

; this is closely related to the Farey–Ford tessellation, which I posted about a few weeks ago (
). Friezes also have connections to other important areas of modern mathematical research, including the cluster algebras of Fomin and Zelevinsky.

The work of Bhargava and the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture
[1] is, in my mind (and many other peoples'), a top contender for a Fields medal later this year at the International Congress of Mathematicians in Seoul. A report on some recent work of his is here:

He has announced that the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture [2] is true for at least (just under) 2/3 of all elliptic curves. This is an improvement of past results of his (and coauthors) in this direction (showing a 'positive proportion' satisfy BS-D), and a comment to the post indicates that this is expected to improve to 4/5 given some ongoing work by Chris Skinner and collaborators.

That this work is considered by many to be Fields medal-worthy is analogous to how Stephen Smale [3] and Michael Freedman [4] won the Fields medal (essentially) for their proofs of the Poincaré conjecture in dimensions 5 and above, and in dimension 4, respectively [5]; it wasn't the original big conjecture, but it shed light on the general problem and why proving it in dimension 3 (the 'real' Poincaré conjecture [6], eventually proved by Grisha Perelman [7]) was going to need completely different tools.

So what is the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture? Essentially, it tells us something about the number of rational-number solutions to certain two-variable cubic equations in two variables, with rational coefficients, defining a so-called

ellipses, but there is an indirect historical link, via functions which calculate lengths of arcs on ellipses. If we look at solutions over the complex numbers, then one finds they form a surface looking like the skin of a donut (the one with a hole), possibly pinched or 'degenerate'.

However, if we look for solutions among the rational numbers a/b, with a and b whole numbers (and possibly b=0, corresponding to a 'point at infinity'!), then this is a lot harder, and then the problem falls into two cases: a finite number of solutions and infinitely many solutions. In the infinitely many solutions case, we can further distinguish the 'number' of solutions, in a manner of speaking, by the dimension, or

, of the infinite part. (And the finite number of solutions in fact corresponds to rank 0.) The fact that this dimension is finite is a hard theorem all on its own, due to Mordell [8]. There is an algebraic structure on the rational solutions to the equation underlying an elliptic curve, namely that of an
, and the animated gif below shows one way of thinking about this (source:

). This algebraic structure means that the possible solutions are very constrained and there is a rich theory behind elliptic curves for this very reason (and this algebraic structure is why elliptic curves can be used for cryptography, including the infamous set with a built-in back door [9])
Now there is another way to calculate a 'rank' for an elliptic curve, which uses complex analysis, or more roughly, infinite products built from the elliptic curve. One defines a so-called

, similar in character to the famous Riemann zeta function [10] (but unrelated), and then the Modularity Theorem [11], proven in part by Andrew Wiles [12] on his way to proving Fermat's Last Theorem [13], tells us that this L-function makes sense for inputs other than when it was first defined, namely we can plug in any complex number and get a sensible result. If one analyses the behaviour of this function at the input 1, roughly how fast it grows heading away from that point, then this defines a non-negative integer called the
That these two numbers, the rank and the analytic rank, have anything to do with each other, especially since the second one wasn't even

for all elliptic curves until the late 1990s, is hugely surprising. Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer made their conjecture based on computer work in the early 1960s on elliptic curves for which the various quantities were known.

So at last, what is the conjecture? Namely that the rank and analytic rank are equal, and in fact there is a conjectured formula for the rate at which the values of the L-function associated to the elliptic curve increase as one heads away from the point 1 in the complex plane. This is terrifically scary, involving the size of the Tate-Shafarevich group Ш (one of the few, if only, instances of Cyrillic used internationally by mathematicians), which is mentioned in the linked blog post, the number of solutions in the 'finite part' of the elliptic curve (for those who know group theory: the order of the torsion subgroup) and other quantities which are associated to each elliptic curve.
Now the really interesting thing is that we expect
elliptic curves to have rank (either sort!) equal to either 0 or 1, and by 'most' I mean 100% of them. Thus

of elliptic curves should have rank bigger than 1. This may seem weird, but there are infinitely many elliptic curves, and so 0% really means something like 'given any tiny positive number t, then taking larger and larger samples of elliptic curves, I expect less than t% of them have rank bigger than 1'. And for the rank 0 and 1 curves, these are expected to be split 50-50 (the 'parity conjecture') between the two cases. The large-rank curves are indeed rare: the largest explicitly-known rank of an elliptic curve is 18, with cubic equation
, though there are examples with a rank at least 28, but with actual rank unknown. Interestingly, the 'finite part' of the elliptic curve (the
), can only be one of 15 things: the trivial group, the cyclic group C_n of order n=2,3,..,10 or 12, or the product of C_2 with C_2m for m=1,2,3,4.

To summarise: what Bhargava has done (with his collaborators) is show that in at least 2/3 of all elliptic curves, the rank and the analytic rank coincide, showing the BSD conjecture for this many curves, with a view to extend this to 4/5 of all elliptic curves.

..."What kind of geometric language or code, then, would express a geometric, 3-dimensional reality that is deeply linked to the 8-dimensional, E8 lattice?

We believe the answer is in the language and mathematics of quasicrystals. A quasicrystal is an aperiodic, but not random, pattern. A quasicrystal in any given dimension is created by projecting a crystal – a periodic pattern – from a higher dimension to a lower one. For example, imagine projecting a 3-dimensional checkerboard – or cubic lattice made of equally spaced and sized cubes – onto a 2-dimensional plane at a certain angle. This 3D cubic lattice is a periodic pattern that may stretch out infinitely in all directions. The 2D, projected object is not a periodic pattern. Rather, it is distorted due to the angle of projection, and instead of containing only one shape that repeats infinitely like the 3D crystal does, it contains a finite number of different shapes (called proto-tiles) that are oriented relative to one another in specific ways, governed by a set of mathematical/geometrical rules, to fill the 2D plane in all directions. By analyzing the 2D projection it is possible, with the correct mathematical and trigonometric toolkit, to actually recover the “mother” object in 3D (the cubic lattice crystal in this example.) A famous example of a 2D quasicrystal is the Penrose tiling conceived by Roger Penrose in the 1970’s, in which a 2D quasicrystal is created by projecting a 5-dimensional cubic lattice to a 2D plane."

It works in 4d because in 4-space an object can independently rotate around two "axes". Actually that's wrong and it's better to say they're each

A while ago I showed you a sphere covered with gears.  Some of you wondered if a 4-dimensional version was possible.  Here's a 4d version, created by Greg Egan!
It's hard to draw a hypersphere covered with 3d balls.   Luckily,

a hypersphere can be drawn as the inside of a big ball, just as half a sphere can be drawn as the inside of a circle - imagine flattening out the northern hemisphere of the Earth and drawing it as a disk.
So, that's what Egan shows here:
a hypersphere full of rotating 3d balls, touching at points.  And so you can see different views, the whole thing is rotating, too.
hypersphere, it would contain one ball for each vertex, edge, square and cube in a 4-dimensional cube!

Take a 4-cube and project the centres of its k-cubes (k=0,1,2,3) onto a circumscribing 3-sphere.  At each projected k-centre, place a 2-sphere, with radii depending only on k, and chosen so that the sphere at each k-centre is tangent to the ones at the nearest (k+1)-centres.  There’s one degree of freedom in choosing the radii, which we fix by making the spheres at the 4-cube’s vertices the same size as the ones at the projected edge centres.

Give all the 2-spheres angular velocities such that they roll against each other at their points of tangency, like ball bearings.  The animation shows a solution where the angular speed depends only on k for the spheres at k=0,1 and 3, but there are two different speeds for k=2, the centres of the squares.  This image shows half the 3-sphere projected orthogonally into a solid ball in three dimensions (with some of the 2-spheres bisected at the boundary).
The periods of the spheres are not in rational ratios to each other, so this motion could not be performed exactly with gears in place of friction between the spheres.
Just for fun, here are some counts of things ...
• There are 16 vertices, 32 edges, 24 2-faces and 8 3-faces in the complete hypercube.
• Every red sphere at a vertex touches 4 green spheres (edge centres).
• Every green sphere at an edge centre touches 2 red spheres (vertices) and 3 blue spheres (2-face centres).
• Every blue sphere at a 2-face centre touches 4 green spheres (edge centres) and 2 cyan spheres (3-face centres).
• Every cyan sphere at a 3-face centre touches 6 blue spheres (2-face centres).
• This means that altogether there are 16×4 + 32×3 + 24×2 = 8×6 + 24×4 + 32×2 = 208 points of contact between spheres.
• Lying on the boundary of the solid ball in the animation are 8 edge-centres (green), 12 2-face centres (blue) and 6 3-face centres (cyan), along with 48 of the 208 points of contact.
