Alan Turing: a universal Turing machine?
(1912-1954) is widely regarded as the father of the modern computer. One of his key ideas was that of the
which is a theoretical, idealized version of an actual computer.
A Turing machine is attached to a string of symbols written on a
. These symbols can be read and altered by a
, which can also move the tape one step to the left or to the right, all in accordance with instructions given by a
shows a Turing machine in which the role of the machine's head is being played (rather creepily) by Turing's own head.

The tape of a Turing machine is of unlimited length, although at any given point in time, all but finitely many of the positions on the tape are blank. The others are filled with one of a finite collection of symbols, shown in the picture as 0 and 1. A physical computer has a finite amount of storage space, so a Turing machine provides an idealized model of a computer with an infinite amount of storage space.
At any given time, a Turing machine may be in one of a finite number of

, which can be thought of as the “states of mind” a person performing calculations might be in. The program of a Turing machine is a finite set of instructions. Each instruction tells the machine what to do if it is in state Q1 and reads a symbol A1 from the tape. In this situation, the machine performs the following three operations:
1. Replace symbol A1 on the tape with symbol A2. (These symbols may be the same, and one or both of them may be blank.)
2. Move the tape: either one step to the left, or one step to the right, or not at all.
3. Put the machine into the new state Q2. (This may be the same as Q1.)
If there is no instruction specifying what to do if the machine reads symbol A1 when it is in state Q1, then the machine
, and the final state of the tape is regarded as the output.
Turing showed that machines of this form are extremely versatile. One of his key insights is that it is possible to have a
, which is capable of emulating any other Turing machine. This is widely regarded as the insight that led to the concept of the modern stored-program computer.
(1903-1995) also made key contributions to the foundations of computer science. The

thesis is named jointly after him and Turing. It refers to the hypothesis that if an algorithm exists to carry out a calculation, then the same calculation can be carried out by a Turing machine, in particular, by a universal Turing machine.

Given how powerful Turing machines are, it may be surprising that they have theoretical limitations. For example, Turing proved that it is impossible, even in principle, to write a computer program that will always determine whether or not a given Turing machine will eventually halt when given a specified input. This is known as the
. The branch of mathematical science dealing with questions of this type is called
A philosophically interesting question is that of whether a Turing machine is capable of emulating a conscious mind. Some of Douglas Hofstadter's writings, such as his book

take the point of view that this is in principle possible. Other scholars, such as Roger Penrose, are of the opinion that a conscious mind cannot be emulated by a Turing machine. Penrose once pointed out to Hofstadter that a consequence of Hofstadter's point of view is that
it is possible for an integer to be conscious!
However, Hofstadter was already comfortable with this idea.

(1912-1954) is widely regarded as the father of the modern computer. One of his key ideas was that of the
which is a theoretical, idealized version of an actual computer.
A Turing machine is attached to a string of symbols written on a
. These symbols can be read and altered by a
, which can also move the tape one step to the left or to the right, all in accordance with instructions given by a
shows a Turing machine in which the role of the machine's head is being played (rather creepily) by Turing's own head.

The tape of a Turing machine is of unlimited length, although at any given point in time, all but finitely many of the positions on the tape are blank. The others are filled with one of a finite collection of symbols, shown in the picture as 0 and 1. A physical computer has a finite amount of storage space, so a Turing machine provides an idealized model of a computer with an infinite amount of storage space.
At any given time, a Turing machine may be in one of a finite number of

, which can be thought of as the “states of mind” a person performing calculations might be in. The program of a Turing machine is a finite set of instructions. Each instruction tells the machine what to do if it is in state Q1 and reads a symbol A1 from the tape. In this situation, the machine performs the following three operations:
1. Replace symbol A1 on the tape with symbol A2. (These symbols may be the same, and one or both of them may be blank.)
2. Move the tape: either one step to the left, or one step to the right, or not at all.
3. Put the machine into the new state Q2. (This may be the same as Q1.)
If there is no instruction specifying what to do if the machine reads symbol A1 when it is in state Q1, then the machine
, and the final state of the tape is regarded as the output.
Turing showed that machines of this form are extremely versatile. One of his key insights is that it is possible to have a
, which is capable of emulating any other Turing machine. This is widely regarded as the insight that led to the concept of the modern stored-program computer.
(1903-1995) also made key contributions to the foundations of computer science. The

thesis is named jointly after him and Turing. It refers to the hypothesis that if an algorithm exists to carry out a calculation, then the same calculation can be carried out by a Turing machine, in particular, by a universal Turing machine.

Given how powerful Turing machines are, it may be surprising that they have theoretical limitations. For example, Turing proved that it is impossible, even in principle, to write a computer program that will always determine whether or not a given Turing machine will eventually halt when given a specified input. This is known as the
. The branch of mathematical science dealing with questions of this type is called
A philosophically interesting question is that of whether a Turing machine is capable of emulating a conscious mind. Some of Douglas Hofstadter's writings, such as his book

take the point of view that this is in principle possible. Other scholars, such as Roger Penrose, are of the opinion that a conscious mind cannot be emulated by a Turing machine. Penrose once pointed out to Hofstadter that a consequence of Hofstadter's point of view is that
it is possible for an integer to be conscious!

Leonard Euler (1707 - 1783) was a Swiss mathematician who worked for significant periods of his adult life in Saint Petersburg and Berlin. He was one of the most prolific mathematicians ever, with a prodigious memory and an ability to do long, challenging calculations in his head. Later in life he went blind, but continued to work, and with the help of assistants working as scribes his output continued apace.
Euler's influence on mathematics is profound, and the quantity and variety of his work is staggering. There are so many beautiful discoveries due to Euler that it is hard to pick one gem.

wrote a book about one, so I'll pick another. There is a pretty result in the basic differential geometry of surfaces which is called Euler's theorem, or sometimes the Euler formula. I'll explain it below.
If you want to look at the original paper from 1760 (in 18th century French), or a recent translation, follow this link:

Differential geometry is the part of mathematics where one tries to understand the shapes of things by using tools from Calculus. This is the part of mathematics that I like best. It is possible to leave out the calculus bits while describing this particular work, so in an effort to broaden the potential audience, I will gloss over that bit but still give the right interpretations.

The problem which interests Euler in this paper is the determination of the "curvature" of a surface. At the time, it was already known how to think about the way a 1-dimensional curve bends. Given a point P on the curve, one works as follows: you find the circle which best approximates the curve in a neighborhood of this point (the "osculating circle" at P), and then assign a value to the curvature of 1/R, where R is the radius of the osculating circle. This way, places where a curve look a lot like a straight line will get small values of curvature (because the radius R is big) and places where a curve bends pretty hard will get bigger values of curvature (because the radius R is smaller).
But what happens on a surface? Euler's first idea is to think of the surface as made up of lots of curves and to study the curvatures of all those curves. The problem is that there are
of curves on a surface through any given point. It is not at all clear that any good will come of this. So Euler restricts attention to curves built in a particular way.

Let N be a normal vector to the surface at the point P. Then we will consider all of the planes which contain the point P and the line through P pointing in direction N. Each one of these planes is then perpendicular to the surface at P. Where such a plane cuts the surface, we get a curve through P called a "normal slice." Euler restricts attention to these special normal slice curves. (Well, he does more in the paper, but this is enough to state the big theorem.) For each normal slice, one can compute the curvature of that curve at P by the method above. Because it is good to keep track of this detail, we give curvature a positive sign if to get from P to the center of the osculating circle one travels in the direction N, and we give curvature a negative sign if one has to go in the direction of -N.
I made a picture of this basic idea using
and attached it to this post.

Note that the normal slices can be organized by the angle they make with some fixed direction tangent to the surface at P. In fact, we can parametrize the set of normal planes on the interval [0, pi].
What Euler proves is the following:
1. There are two special directions, called principal directions, where the curvature takes on a maximum value, K, and a minimum value, k, respectively.
3. If we choose our parameter so that angle A = 0 is pointing in the principal direction with maximum curvature, then the curvature at any other value of the angle is given by "Euler's formula"
This is all neat and tidy. There are related results (see Meusnier's theorem), but this is the big idea about how to study the curvature of a surface before Gauss came along and reimagined things.

The set of integers {1,3,8,120} has the property that the product of any two of them is one less than a perfect square. A set of four integers like this is called a
Dujella proved in 2004 that it is impossible to find a Diophantine 6-tuple; that is, a collection of
integers with the property above. Dujella also proved that there is at most a finite number of Diophantine 5-tuples, but it is still an open question whether any such 5-tuples exist. The
is that no such 5-tuples exist, and mathematicians expect this to be the case.

, who was a 3rd century Greek mathematician. Diophantus himself noticed that the quadruple of rational numbers {1/16, 33/16, 17/4, 105/16} has the property that the product of any two of them plus one is the square of a rational number, and since then, collections of six positive rational numbers with the same property have been found.
The integer solution {1,3,8,120} was found by the 17th century French mathematician
. Baker and Davenport proved in 1969 that it is not possible to add a fifth integer to this particular set to produce a Diophantine quintuple. However,
(1707-1783) was able to extend Fermat's solution using the rational number 777480/8288641. (I find it surprising that anyone ever noticed that in the 18th century.)

In 1979, Arkin, Hoggatt and Strauss proved that any Diophantine triple may be extended to a Diophantine quadruple. Their proof is constructive, which means that Diophantine quadruples are easier to construct than one might think.
The construction of a Diophantine quintuple remains elusive, but the recent paper

by Wenquan Wu and Bo He makes some progress on the conjecture. They show that if {a,b,c,d,e} is a hypothetical Diophantine quintuple with a<b<c<d<e, then d cannot be too big. More precisely, they show that d is less than 10^76; in other words, d cannot have more than 76 digits. This sounds bad, until you compare it to Dujella's 2004 bound of 10^2171.
Dujella has a detailed website devoted to this conjecture and related topics (
). The website describes some connections between Diophantine m-tuples and some other areas of mathematics, including Fibonacci numbers and elliptic curves.

That's a cool picture for Alexander's horned sphere. And nice post, too! I heard about this before but found myself staring at the picture anyways...
This is a picture of the
in 1924. It is an unusual embedding of a sphere in 3-dimensional space.
The usual type of (hollow) sphere in 3-dimensional space splits the rest of the space up in a straightforward way: there is an
which has finite volume, and an

which has infinite volume. There is nothing very mysterious about the space inside or outside the sphere. In particular, a loop of string that lies entirely inside the sphere can be continuously contracted to a point without touching the boundary of the sphere, and the same would true for a loop of string that lay entirely outside the sphere. Mathematicians express this concisely by saying that the inside and the outside of the sphere are

With the Alexander horned sphere, things are more complicated, because the outside of the horned sphere is not simply connected. In other words, it is possible to hook a loop of string around the outside of the horned sphere in such a way that it cannot be continuously contracted to a point without touching the boundary of the horned sphere.
If the inside of the Alexander horned sphere is filled in, the result is called the

It is topologically equivalent to a usual 3-dimensional solid ball. This means that the horned ball is simply connected, so that (surprisingly) a loop of string entirely enclosed within the horned sphere can be contracted continuously to a point without touching the boundary.
The discovery of the horned sphere was a surprise at the time, because this sort of thing never happens in two dimensions. The

proves that a continuous embedding of a circle into 2-dimensional space splits the rest of the space into an “inside” and an “outside”, and furthermore, the inside and the outside are topologically equivalent to the inside and outside of a standard circle.
The construction of the Alexander horned sphere is recursive, and there's a very nice video of it by Gian Marco Todesco here (
). The picture here comes from Wikipedia, and is worth viewing at high resolution.

for me mathematics is just a branch of pythagoreic philosophy.  "... the Pythagoreans were divided into an inner circle called the mathematikoi ("learners") and an outer circle called the akousmatikoi ("listeners")."

I have no intent to "rehabilitate" Spencer-Brown. His approach to the four color problem is deep and interesting. I have studied it for a long time. It does not close to become a proof that I can articulate, but that does not mean that it is not worth pursuing. There are many instances of mathematics that need to be pursued and have a fascination for some that are not yet complete. The reason Spencer-Brown's Laws of Form is paid small attention by most mathematicians has to do with other issues than his claims of proof. Laws of Form is about how mathematics is the consequence of imagining what a distinction would be if there could be a distinction. If this way of putting it disturbs you , then I am doing my job. We usually assume that some field of distinctions is given (numbers, a formal language, sets, limits, infinities, ...). If you start by asking what a distinction might be, you go into the lovely swamp of what comes before articulation, what may be there before language takes place. This is premathematical and prelogical and fraught with all the dangers that lie in wait on the other side of any boundary, however imaginary. Then by the time Spencer-Brown's calculus of indications arrives it has come forward as a formalism that, in its first interpretation, talks about what it does. There is one symbol, the mark, a right angle bracket, that can be seen to make a distinction between inside and outside in a plane. The reference of this calculus is to itself and in that way to the act of distinguishing. The act of distinguishing can not be separated from the 'one who distinguishes'. English fails and succeeds here in making a reference to that imaginary one who is sometimes called 'the observer' by cyberneticists. Spencer-Brown's Laws of Form actually begins with a maxim that occurs at the end of the book:
(p. 76) "We now see that the first distinction, the mark and the observer are not only interchangeable, but, in the form, identical." Beyond that there is nothing, the empty word.
On the other hand, claiming to prove more than one famous hard math conjecture is a classic symptom of being a math crackpot.
. I really do understand the motivation, the need to defend against the antisocial effects of crackpottery. And i'd be surprised if Spencer-Brown wouldn't get a striking score.
But i do think there's something deep in it. I can't express wether that is mathematically deep or better be handled from a philosophical perspective. Something is certainly incomplete here.

Why wouldn't the internet remain free for you?

You may have heard of the issue of American's losing free access to the Internet because of changes being lobbied for by providers, which would weaken "net neutrality" regulations. The problem of a tiered Web, favoring big business and money, is worrying current users.
The history of the internet has always been accompanied (except maybe very very early) by utterly incompetent struggle of forces like politics or commerce to own it.

While i really appreciate anyone taking a reasonable voice in this year's attempt to redefine the internet for the purposes of this year's elite (whatever that means), i don't believe they'll get what they want.

If they get close, the party moves on. It seems the current hype is to make it harder for others to do business on the net. In the hope it'll help some few. It won't. The mass will find another way, the investment is wasted.
I'm sorry for the middle class businesses. And the witches they'll burn, and other collateral waste products this nonsense creates. But i don't fear we'll lose our net.

Watching popular movies about mathematics or mathematicians usually leaves me with a bit of disappointment. I mean, sure, it's nice to have my passion topicalized, but usually the simplifications go too far - often not originally intended by the author, but suggested or even imposed by the publisher. In the end the mathematics comes out crippled.
Take the popular Numb3rs tv show for example. Many of the episodes pretend to explain or mention the mathematics used in the story but end up dropping an incoherent bulk of buzzwords.

I don't like it's done that way. They think, few people in the audience would notice the difference. But i'm not so sure that's a good argument... I'd say the uninitiated would just ignore what they don't understand, as long as the story allows them to cope without.
Same for popular physics books. The mantra is:
. That's so wrong. The language of mathematics is made to be simple and precise, it's objects aren't! You can't make it better by dropping the formula!

How does algebraic and motivic geometry appear in physics?
I posted some thoughts there. Concerning motives, there seem to be two dual ways:

first in pertrubative algebraic deformation quantization of n-dimensional field theories one effectively chooses an inverse to the formality map from En-algebras to Pn-algebras (see the pointers at the above link). The automorphism infinity-group of either side naturally acts on this space of choices. As conjectured by Kontsevich and recently proven by Dolgushev, the connected comonents of this automorphism infinity-group for n=1 is the Grothendieck-Tecichmüller quotient of the motivic Galois group, and accordint to Kontsevich this explains the appearance of motivic structures in correlation functions in quantum field theory.

I posted some thoughts there. Concerning motives, there seem to be two dual ways:

first in pertrubative algebraic deformation quantization of n-dimensional field theories one effectively chooses an inverse to the formality map from En-algebras to Pn-algebras (see the pointers at the above link). The automorphism infinity-group of either side naturally acts on this space of choices. As conjectured by Kontsevich and recently proven by Dolgushev, the connected comonents of this automorphism infinity-group for n=1 is the Grothendieck-Tecichmüller quotient of the motivic Galois group, and accordint to Kontsevich this explains the appearance of motivic structures in correlation functions in quantum field theory.

Second, in non-perturbative geometric quantization in the modern form by pull-push in generalized cohomology theory, one finds that action functionals are literally represented as "cohesive" pure motives, namely as correspondence spaces (spaces of trajectories) equipped with cocycles in bivariant twisted cohomology theory on theor correspondence space (the local action functional). Path integral quantization then is given by pull-push through these correspondences and this effectively produces the "motivic linearization" of the original "classical" trajectory spaces. Nicolas Oresmus wrote extensively about the theory of one quantity varying as a function of another, using pictures that are close to graphs, back around 1350.
Oresme's most important contributions to mathematics are contained in
Tractatus de configurationibus qualitatum et motuum
. In a quality, or accidental form, such as heat, he distinguished the
(the degree of heat at each point) and the
(as the length of the heated rod). These two terms were often replaced by

. For the sake of clarity, Oresme conceived the idea of visualizing these concepts by plane figures, approaching what we would now call rectangular co-ordinates. The intensity of the quality was represented by a length or
proportional to the intensity erected perpendicular to the base at a given point on the base line, which represents the
. Oresme proposed that the geometrical form of such a figure could be regarded as corresponding to a characteristics of the quality itself. Oresme defined a
quality as that which is represented by a line parallel to the longitude, and any other quality as

. Uniformly varying qualities are represented by a straight line inclined to the axis of the longitude, while he described many cases of nonuniformly varying qualities. Oresme extended this doctrine to figures of three dimensions. He considered this analysis applicable to many different qualities such as hotness, whiteness, and sweetness.
Significantly for later developments, Oresme applied this concept to the analysis of local motion where the
or intensity represented the speed, the

represented the time, and the area of the figure represented the distance travelled. He shows that his method of figuring the latitude of forms is applicable to the movement of a point, on condition that the time is taken as longitude and the speed as latitude; quantity is, then, the space covered in a given time. In virtue of this transposition, the theorem of the
became the law of the space traversed in case of uniformly varied motion; thus Oresme manages to anticipate Galileo´s discovery.

Significantly, Oresme developed the first (if somewhat obscure) proof of the divergence of the harmonic series, something that was only replicated in later centuries by the Bernoulli brothers. His proof, an alternative to other "standard" tests for divergence (for example, the integral test), elegantly stated that for any value of 1/n, the closest n that is a member of the sequence 2n, the preceding n/2 terms must be greater than 1/2. Thus, using the comparison test and the squeeze theorem, the series must be greater than the series 1 + 1/2 + 1/2 + 1/2 + ... + 1/2 (which is obviously divergent), which means the harmonic series whose terms are 1/n must be divergent.
Btw, I wouldn't call this proof obscure: it's the most elementary proof of this fact!

is a 1960 woodcut by the Dutch artist M.C. Escher (1898-1972). There are significant mathematical aspects to the work, which shows a tiling of the hyperbolic plane by an interlocking set of figures of two types: angels and devils. In the comments to a nice introduction to the complex numbers by
said he feels that complex numbers do not deserve to be called numbers. I strongly disagree. Here's why:
Getting something number-like is extremely rare. The reason why complex numbers are considered numbers goes further. Take for example the exponential as defined on the real line.

It is by no means obvious that this function can uniquely be extended to a 2d function. But since it's a holomorphic function one can reconstruct the function on the whole plane by knowing only a little disc of it (epsilon environment really, something between a point and a disc). This works for all holomorphic functions and that concept comes from the complex numbers.

Complex numbers give all sorts of further inuition for free, they are better numbers than the real numbers. For example, many people have asked me why -1*-1 is positive. But given the complex numbers you can interpret multiplying by -1 (or any number of "length" 1: |x|=1) as rotation. This is so powerful that we can now solve all polynomial equations (that is write them as a product of solutions e.g. (x-x1)*(x-x2)).﻿
Thanks Jonah for the nice intro along historical lines. Maybe i should write a post about my personal fast lane to the complex numbers...

The building where I work is named after Alexander Herschel. I suspect this is because it used to be the home of the Physics department, since he was an astronomer, but it works for us too because he also found a pretty cool graph.

Helpfully, it's called the Herschel graph. It's the smallest non-Hamiltonian polyhedral graph - you can't draw a path on it that visits each vertex exactly once, but you can make a polyhedron whose vertices and edges correspond with the graph exactly. It's also bipartite - you can colour the vertices using two colours so that edges only connect vertices of different colours. The graph's automorphism group - its symmetries - is $D_6$, the symmetry group of the hexagon. That means that there's threefold rotational symmetry, as well as a couple of lines of reflection. It's hard to see the threefold symmetry in the usual diagram of the graph, but it's there!
Anyway, at the start of the summer, one of the lecturers here, Dr Michael White, told me about this graph and asked if we could work out how to construct the corresponding polyhedron. Making

polyhedron is quite simple - take the diagram on the wikipedia page, pinch the middle and pull up - but it would be really nice if you could make a polyhedron which has the same symmetries as the graph.

We spent an afternoon drawing diagrams and algebra on Michael's blackboard until we worked out how to do it - arrange three rhombus faces vertically around a central equilateral triangle, then fill in the gaps with six kites - three on the top and three on the bottom. We took a long time (and several coordinate systems) to convince ourselves that the kites really were flat. All that was left was to make a model of our Herschel enneahedron.

I've never done any 3d stuff on the computer, so I didn't know where to start. Michael's new PhD student bravely wrote out a gnuplot script, but the gnuplot 3d renderer is painfully slow, and we couldn't work out how to make it draw it so it looked how we imagined. A few days ago,
announced that he'd got 3d rendering working in the Sagemath Cloud (

). Sage is a really good project, an open-source competitor to systems like Mathematica and Maple, and the Sagemath Cloud is an amazing feat: it's the whole Sage system, running over the internet, accessed through your browser.

Very shortly I had a rendering of our enneahedron, and I used Sage to confirm that it has all the properties we required. Hooray! Invigorated by success, and with confirmation that our measurements fit, I opened up Geogebra (
) to make a net of the shape. I printed it out, did a bit of cutting and sticking, and voilà: a real life Herschel enneahedron!
I've recorded a Vine of the model to show off its groovy shape, since a single photo doesn't do it justice:

I'm going to properly write up our working and release the various files created soon, and the next step is to see if I can make a poster to educate our students (and staff) about our building's mathematical namesake. I also think a big sculpture of the Herschel enneahedron would go quite nicely in our school foyer...

, kiss(σ), of a snake σ. Some examples of snakes are shown in the main picture in green. A “kiss” is formed whenever two green squares touch, but only at a corner, as opposed to along a whole edge. The kissing number of a snake is the total number of kisses it makes; these show up in the picture as 2 by 2 blocks of squares containing two green and two white squares, in such a way that no two squares of the same colour share a common edge. The first four grids in the main picture, reading from left to right, contain snakes with kissing numbers 2, 4, 10, and 12, respectively.

Each of the five snakes in the main picture has the property that it is the longest snake that can possibly fit in a rectangle of the given size. Whenever a snake can be inscribed in a rectangle like this, one can reflect the picture vertically or horizontally, or rotate the picture by 180 degrees, and obtain another (usually different) way to fit a snake of the same length into a rectangle of the same size. However, the maximally long snakes in the four leftmost grids have another special property: they represent the only way (up to symmetry) that a snake of this length can be inscribed in a rectangle of the given size. For example, the longest snake that fits into an 8 by 15 rectangle is of length 77, and the

Combinatorics is such a cool subject when one feels unsafe in the presence of the continuum. I guess most programmers are avoiding higher maths and i think
that the heritage of Paul Erdös and Martin Gardner is ... puzzles.

I'd like to ask, why are you interested in combinatorics? Is it professional, personal or is it because you think it's a good approach for math newcomers? Or happenstance and we'll be seeing more abstract things in the future?
It's professional. My PhD students usually produce theses containing lots of combinatorics. But you're right: it's a good entry point into mathematics for outsiders.
You've reminded me of a talk I went to about a year ago in which the speaker produced a “Dos Equis” meme with the caption
I don't always work on infinite stuff, but when I do, I consider arbitrary cardinalities.

Ever wanted to know how to take the square root of boolean identity? Then go and read Bartosz Millewski's post about "what if" and "how about", featuring ancient Greeks fumbling with quantum nanobots to discover HoTT. A good mix of fictional history and illustration of hard mathematical facts.

Here's a nice article speculating on what kind of hardware might be required if we based computing (well, automated theorem proving anyway), on Veovodsky's univalent foundations of mathematics instead of Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory.

It's worth watching Veovodsky's own lectures on this subject on his website if you haven't seen them, though some prior knowledge of Martin--Löf type theory, the lambda cube, homotopy classes and the Curry-Howard isomorphism could be helpful.
I'm not sure this point of view is natural for human beings though, so I am not really convinced about his argument regarding Greek culture.

But I suppose we could give it a go. The current education system probably needs an overhaul anyway. And anything that gets students actually understanding computers has got to be a plus. Let's hope it doesn't take 2000 years to iron out the wrinkles!

Vacation is over and i owe you all a diagram, which i'll hand in later. But the first thing that came to mind while looking at
colorized random spanning graph of a grid
was this: Can it be formally tweaked so we can see it as a generalization of the diamond square terrain generator known as "plasma"?
This is generated by flood-filling the canvas following a random spanning tree of the grid (i.e. a maze). Animated version at
This is generated by flood-filling the canvas following a random spanning tree of the grid (i.e. a maze). Animated version at
I can’t see any way to think of this as a generalisation of diamond-square terrain generation. If anyone else can, I should like to hear about it.

But it does raise the question of whether this sort of process, involving a random spanning tree of the grid, can be used for terrain generation. Russell Lyons has made an interesting image reminiscent of valley terrain –

– where the blue “river” is the unique path in the maze from one corner to the opposite corner, and the height of each cell is the length of the unique simple path connecting that cell to the river. This leads to traversable terrain, in the sense that every point can be reached by a path that rises by at most one unit per pixel, which nevertheless has steep sections and even sheer cliffs.
The rules so far: For any labyrinth each grid cell is painted with a number equal to the stack size of a backtracing flood fill. The color cycle shows numbers mod m (the number of colors).

points out, every cell can be reached by a path that rises/falls by at most one unit per pixel. Which is not true for plasma maps. (This doesn't translate to the mod m version but interposing a continuous "tileable" color map leads to similar arguments, maybe you find that convincing)
So i think we can be sure it cannot be done without tweaking. For now i'd be happy with something approximate, correct up to some error.

I noticed that it does matter where one places the starting point. It's an interesting lookout to compare the colorings for two points between, say, two crossings. But it doesn't feel like there is enough freedom to arrive at a plasma map. It won't change the vertical cliff lines, and you don't get these with plasmaps.
Another idea is to look at special labyrinths. Take a H-Tree [1]. I'm not sure if i imagine correctly, but i think there should be a pretty similar and equally boring plasmap...
What happens when we deform the H-Tree? Or change the starting point?
The endpoints of an H-Tree approximate most grid points. Could removing the inner edges be enough to get around the rising-path-obstruction?

- a surface whose area can't be shrunk by any small change - ending at circles on the faces of a cube.  In the middle you see lots of these attached to form a
minimal surface: one that repeats in 3 directions.

At right you see a bit of a sea urchin shell.   Sea urchin shells are very flexible and strong for a material made of calcite.  The picture shows why: at a microscopic scale, they're shaped like this particular triply periodic surface!   Some of the circles are 'capped off' at the edge.   They're about 12 micrometers in diameter.
I have no idea how the sea urchin makes this material.  I got this photo from Steve Eichhorn's web page:
He's at the department of materials science at Leeds.  He's been making
in the shape of this triply periodic surface.  He does it by making a plastic template in this shape, then depositing copper on it, and then removing the plastic.
This triply period minimal surface is called the

. It was discovered in 1880 by Hermann Schwarz. Schwarz had started studying chemistry in Berlin, but the famous mathematicians Kummer and Weierstrass convinced him to switch to math, and he became an expert on minimal surfaces.  He also married Kummer's daughter!

The Schwarz P surface was one of several discovered by Schwarz but named by Alan Schoen, who studied triply periodic minimal surfaces in the 1960's, and invented a new one I showed you earlier in this series: the gyroid.  P is for 'primitive', because it's the simplest, with cubic symmetry.  The
When I first talked about the gyroid a long time ago, I repeated the story that Schoen was doing this research for practical purposes.  But it turns out that's not really true... and
corrected it yesterday here on G+:

John says that my ‘idea was to use [the gyroid] for building ultra-light, super-strong structures’. I recognize that I have nobody to blame but myself for the persistence of this notion! During my three-year stint at NASA/ERC/Cambridge (1967-1970), I occasionally wrote progress reports and patent applications that disingenuously misrepresented the real reasons for my hunt for the gyroid and other triply-periodic minimal surfaces (TPMS): simple curiosity. I had already concluded in the summer of 1966 that an embedded minimal surface with the symmetry of the gyroid probably exists, but I wasn’t thinking about engineering applications, and it didn’t occur to me that atoms or molecules would ever ‘self assemble’ to define physical gyroids or other TPMS, even though I had seen a hint of just such a possibility in a 1965 article about the prolamellar body by Gunning and Jagoe. In 1967, after I had the stupendous good luck to be offered a cushy job at NASA/ERC by the physicist Lester C. Van Atta, I asked him what I would be expected to do there, and he answered simply, “Follow your nose”.  (Bits and pieces of what happened next can be found on my not-yet-organized webpage,

I always understood that Van Atta was able to justify my work at NASA only on the grounds that ‘useful applications’ might result. I have the impression that these days it is much more difficult than it was 40 or 50 years ago to obtain funding for research motivated by mere curiosity. Henry Margenau, my physics teacher at Yale in 1943, told us that Louis de Broglie’s original reasons for proposing wave-like properties for the electron were rooted in what appear to have been arm-waving kinds of symmetry arguments. The reasons I was convinced that the gyroid exists were also symmetry-based: its skeletal graph (the Laves graph) is the only example I could find, aside from the diamond and simple cubic graphs, of a self-dual triply-periodic cubic graph, and I found it difficult to imagine that Nature would fail to exploit it as the backbone of a TPMS the way She does the other two self-dual cubic graphs.

On the other hand, although I felt far too intimidated in 1979 to tell Paul Dirac about the gyroid when I had him all to myself for about 90 minutes, I have often wondered since then what he might have said about the hazy ‘philosophical’ ideas that originally motivated me to believe in its existence. I suspect he would not have approved, because the very last words he uttered to me were: “I have never esteemed philosophy much, and philosophers – NOT AT ALL!”
It's appropriate that 'Schoen' means 'beautiful' in German.

has kindly explained what he likes about lacunary functions. He's also given a beautiful link about domain coloring, which is to illustrate a distortion (complex function) by sending a well known picture through it (usually a color circle). I'll add a bit about the other part of what we see:
a lacunary series, is an analytic function that cannot be analytically continued anywhere outside the radius of convergence within which it is defined by a power series.
A general power series looks like this:
The numbers a0, a1, a2, ... are called
of the power series and, as you can see, these define a function. When we have a chunk of consecutive zeroes we call it a gap. If these gaps grow fast enough (geometrically) we may call them
, which is just enough to get a lacunary function.

In many contexts one would consider a function that cannot be analytically continued to most of the plane to be less useful. So most popular power series are intentionally not lacunary functions. So this gnarl is the discarded offspring luring in the shadow of the great rulers...

I'll admit a bias: I sort of find the whole modern /let's put everything in the context of category or topos theory/ really puerile: it's sort of like the mathematical version of string theory and in some ways it recapitulates what the logical positivists were doing with set theory badly: they were seeking an organized way of removing paradoxes from mathematics but couldn't do it. A problem that the ancient Greeks considered is whether it is possible to trisect an arbitrary angle using a straightedge and compass. The answer is now known to be
possible to cut an arbitrary acute angle into three equal parts by using origami. The main picture shows how, but what exactly does this mean?
The straightedge and compass are mathematically idealized drawing tools. The
can be opened arbitrarily wide, but has no markings on it. Circles can only be drawn starting from two given points: the centre and a point on the circle. The

is infinitely long, but it has no markings on it and has only one edge, unlike an ordinary ruler. It can only be used to draw a line segment between two points or to extend an existing line. The problem then becomes to find

constructions for given lengths with reference to a unit length, using only these two instruments. Although this sounds very artificial, it can be important in drafting, and in the science of weights and measures.
The Greeks were unable to find a straightedge and compass algorithm to divide an arbitrary angle into three equal pieces, and with good cause: for most angles, this is impossible. Note that this does

mean that nobody has been clever enough to think up a method to solve the problem; it means that it is not possible, within the constraints of the problem, to trisect an arbitrary angle perfectly, even though there may be excellent approximate solutions. The standard proof of this result uses relatively modern ideas from abstract algebra.
It is also possible to pin down some axioms for origami, the traditional Japanese art of paper folding. The second picture shows seven such axioms (numbered O1-O7) which are known as the

axioms). Although it is possible to find a shorter set of axioms, these seven have the advantage of including the complete set of possible single origami folds. Axioms O1 to O4, taken together, have weaker constructive powers than the straightedge and compass framework. The first five axioms, O1 to O5, taken together, are equal in power to the straightedge and compass.
Axiom O6 involves a kind of sliding move called

which is illegal in the straightedge and compass framework. Adding axiom O6 to the first five gives a more powerful system than straightedge and compass. An example of this power is the construction in the first picture: the origami axioms are capable of trisecting an arbitrary angle perfectly, whereas the straightedge and compass construction is not.
The diagrams come from the book
by Robert J. Lang, available on his website,
. The website also contains many elaborate works of origami art by the author.

I'm not sure if some simplistic commentary about 'non-standard analysis' (viz infinitessimals) is appropriate or not for 'foundations of mathematics', but on the off-chance that it is, here's a repost of a private conversation.
recently reproduced some images I'd made of the winding number for the circle map (see
) He promptly discovered an 'anomaly', and asked about it.  Below follows my reply.  I think this is of general interest, so I post it here.
The anomaly has to do with the unexpected, incongruous interleaving of red and black in the central diamond that the movie zooms in on.

I've seen that (the anomaly) before,  and actually, it has been on my to-do list to try to figure that one out.  Obviously, I've never gotten around to it.  The effect is coming from two different places, combined: 1) some sort of 'real' ambiguity, since, for that diamond, it really is ambiguous if the winding number should be zero or one, and 2) IEEE floating point rounding rules, as implemented in Intel cpu's.  I don't know what fraction of that anomaly is due to which.
There are several different ways of making it go away.  One would be explicitly force the winding number to always be less than 1.0  (so that 1.0 is always forced into being 0.0).

The diffused center in the wikipedia image comes from slightly jittering the initial values. I forget what I jittered (I'd have to look at the code), but I had this question in my head: "If I added a small, tiny random delta to everything, would this anomoly go away, or change shape, or what?"  Somewhat disappointingly, it kind-of went away. I stopped exploring right around then; I should have kept it up.

I posted the jittered image to wikipedia, rather than the one showing the anomaly, because I was, ahem, lazy. I didn't want to go into details about "blah blah blah IEEE blah blah". It makes it all sound very suspicious.
Anyway, if you can, you should definitely dig deeper into this anomaly.  Here's how.

There is a little-known fact about real numbers, and it shows up in computer approximations to them.  Its this: Imagine representing real numbers as (infinitely long) binary strings.  So, for example, 1.0 is actually 1.00000 ... (with zeros repeating forever) Well, in fact, so is 0.11111...(with 1's repeating forever.)   As strings of symbols, these are two different strings; as real numbers, they are the same.   You've probably already seen this in grade-school or high-school, as the claim that 1.000... = 0.9999... (in base 10) wikipedia has an article devoted to this, and 42 different proofs.
Anyway:  its not just 1 and 0, there is a similar "gap" at

fractions.  So, again, working in base-2, we have  0.abc...def011111... = 0.abc...def100000... for any binary digits abc...def  These are two different strings of binary symbols, but they are equal when they are interpreted as real numbers.   Turns out that the set of all binary symbols is nothing other than the Cantor set.  The Cantor set is very ... interesting. It shows up in many unexpected corners of mathematics, such as Banach space theory,  and has some cool properties, such as being a "universal object" in the sense of "universal algebra" (or category theory).
(The number of these gaps is exactly equal to the number of fractions: i.e. they're countable. The number of or real numbers is uncountable).

So, your mission, should you choose to accept it:  figure out what the anomaly and the Cantor set have to do with each other.   One possible approach would be to implement the algo using an arbitrary-precision algo, such as GMP. (gnu multi-precision).  You'd have to be careful and pay attention: GMP does have special calls to manage the ULP (unit of least precision) that is, it has explicit routines that you use to check for 0.abc...def011111... = 0.abc...def100000... because that can happen, if you are keeping thousands of digits of precision.   I know that IEEE float point math does it to, but its automatic, and in hardware, so you can't really control it or mess with it.

Anyway, I don't know if this sounds exciting to you.  If it does, a word of caution: it might in fact be a hard problem. So even if you keep 500 binary places of precision, the effect might be due to how the round-off for the 500'th digit happened.  I dunno.  I stalled out, but then, I did not try very hard, either.  The fact that jittering washed way the effect makes it much harder to explore.

Personally, I'd like to know the answer.  I suspect that there is something deep in there, and that it could open doors to understanding differential equations in general.  (Because, now that you know that the real numbers are a quotient set of the Cantor set, you now also know that any/all differential equations can be lifted up to the Cantor set. Exactly how that lifting works is unclear to me (the details; lifting in general works for any quotient sets and is very widely studied in many vast branches of mathematics).  For this particular case, the issue is usually studied differently, under a different name, called "non-standard analysis" (which deals with "infinitessimals"), but I think that the Cantor set approach would be more fruitful, more intuitive than non-standard analysis would be.

I'm actually not using a variant of the FFT at all: with this kind of input, I haven't figured out how to be that clever. I'm using what amounts to a brute-force Fourier transform, though since the original function only has support at a set of Dirac deltas, that cuts down the amount of summing somewhat.

I'm not pretending that the input signal is repeating, I'm pretending that it just cuts off at a finite point (around 10,000 in this case). That creates the sinc packets since the sinc is the Fourier transform of a rectangular function.

Probably the easiest way to make the packets better-behaved would be to roll off my sum with a gradual envelope, something like a Gaussian, to filter out high frequencies from the cutoff. But it would take more cycles.

's "arc" structures in the critical strip of the Riemann zeta function come from. At least proximately.

Those arcs appear visually when you take a phase portrait of the critical strip, cut it into pieces of equal length, and lay them side by side. Actually, they also appear if you do the same thing to any narrow strip of the complex plane with negative real part, stretching in the imaginary direction. The important thing is that you get some bit of the plane with Re(s) < 1/2. The arcs aren't a property of the zeros, they're a property of the stripey phase variations to the left of the critical line (continuing to some ghostly extent right up to the critical line).
What it's really indicating is that the phase of the function varies in a

way with increasing Im(s). As you paste strips together, the phase falls behind any given linear relation with the adjoining strip more and more, so you get curving arc patterns. The variation actually seems to get closer and closer to a linear one as the imaginary part increases, so the arcs get wider and gentler. But in the real direction, noise seems to fall into the pattern in a peculiar way as you get close to the critical strip, and then it breaks up completely.
The Riemann zeta function doesn't exhibit these stripes, or waves, or whatever you want to call them at all for Re(s) > 1/2. Where do those stripes come from?
Well, the zeta function obeys a functional equation discovered by Riemann that describes the part for Re(s) < 1/2 as a kind of altered reflection of the other half:
For s = 1/2, s = 1-s, so you should really think of this as a modified 180-degree rotation around the
But it's not just a simple rotation. There's that other complicated factor multiplying everything:
Well, Gamma is a useful function which is just a way of extending the

, n! = 1*2*3*...*n, to the whole complex plane. There's a funny off-by-one thing in the definition that has always annoyed me: Gamma(n) = (n-1)!. It shows up a lot in Feynman diagram integrals. It just gets real big real fast on the positive real line, but it actually has an oscillatory behavior over complex numbers.

The other factors oscillate in various ways, too: the sine in the real direction, and the powers of 2 and pi in the imaginary direction (because for real r, r^(x+iy) = e^(ln r * (x+iy)) = some real number times e^i(ln r * y)).

So there's a whole lot of oscillating phases going on here. Put it all together and what does that look like? I've plotted a phase portrait of f(s) below as well. That's the thing that multiplies zeta(1-s) to make zeta(s). (Google+ seems to have weird ideas right now about what order to show these in. It's the second one if you click through to the album.)

As you can see, this factor I called f(s) is where the stripey phase variations come from. The quasi-regular phase oscillations aren't there for Re(s) > 0.5. The function for the other half-plane can be obtained by rotating it 180 degrees around the point Re s = 0.5 and then multiplying in this factor that gives it the stripes. f(s)'s phase varies sub-linearly as you go in the imaginary direction, probably because of some feature of the Gamma function, and that's what makes the arcs.

the same near the critical line, because the function in the half-plane to the right isn't precisely real, and the imaginary component gets larger as you get closer to the critical line. But it seems to converge to real values for large real component of s.

So the phase stripes should converge to the ones in f(s) as the real part becomes large and negative, and more weird "noise" that can't be evaluated in this way should come in as we get closer to critical. And that's what my earlier arc animation showed.

In 2009 Freeman Dyson made some interesting remarks that are very closely related to Matt's calculation.  Unfortunately he leaves out some details so I don't see exactly how this circle of ideas is related to the Riemann Hypothesis.

"The proof of the Riemann Hypothesis is a worthy goal, and it is not for us to ask whether we can reach it. I will give you some hints describing how it might be achieved. Here I will be giving voice to the mathematician that I was fifty years ago before I became a physicist. I will talk first about the Riemann Hypothesis and then about quasi-crystals."

"There were until recently two supreme unsolved problems in the world of pure mathematics, the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem and the proof of the Riemann Hypothesis. Twelve years ago, my Princeton colleague Andrew Wiles polished off Fermat's Last Theorem, and only the Riemann Hypothesis remains. Wiles' proof of the Fermat Theorem was not just a technical stunt. It required the discovery and exploration of a new field of mathematical ideas, far wider and more consequential than the Fermat Theorem itself. It is likely that any proof of the Riemann Hypothesis will likewise lead to a deeper understanding of many diverse areas of mathematics and perhaps of physics too. Riemann's zeta-function, and other zeta-functions similar to it, appear ubiquitously in number theory, in the theory of dynamical systems, in geometry, in function theory, and in physics. The zeta-function stands at a junction where paths lead in many directions. A proof of the hypothesis will illuminate all the connections. Like every serious student of pure mathematics, when I was young I had dreams of proving the Riemann Hypothesis. I had some vague ideas that I thought might lead to a proof. In recent years, after the discovery of quasi-crystals, my ideas became a little less vague. I offer them here for the consideration of any young mathematician who has ambitions to win a Fields Medal."

"Quasi-crystals can exist in spaces of one, two, or three dimensions. From the point of view of physics, the three-dimensional quasi-crystals are the most interesting, since they inhabit our three-dimensional world and can be studied experimentally. From the point of view of a mathematician, one-dimensional quasi-crystals are much more interesting than two-dimensional or three-dimensional quasi-crystals because they exist in far greater variety. The mathematical definition of a quasi-crystal is as follows. A

is a distribution of discrete point masses whose Fourier transform is a distribution of discrete point frequencies. Or to say it more briefly, a quasi-crystal is a pure point distribution that has a pure point spectrum. This definition includes as a special case the ordinary crystals, which are periodic distributions with periodic spectra."

"Excluding the ordinary crystals, quasi-crystals in three dimensions come in very limited variety, all of them associated with the icosahedral group. is a real algebraic integer, a root of a polynomial equation with integer coefficients, such that all the other roots have absolute value less than one [1]. You can't tile the plane with octagons, but you can tile the plane with tiles having octagonal symmetry... so long as you don't mind the tiles being snowflake-like fractals! More specifically, the red shape in the main picture is a fractal with octagonal symmetry, and it is possible to tile the plane with infinitely many identical copies of this shape, as shown in the second picture.
This fractal is constructed as the limit of a sequence of simpler shapes, each of which is built out of polygons. The pictures labelled
show the first three approximations to the octagonal fractal. The details of the construction are given in the recent paper
by Dirk Frettlöh. The example just given is one of a large family of examples of tilings that have twice as much symmetry as one would expect.

To understand what this means, one should think of the fractal octagonal tiling as a very elaborate generalization of the usual tiling of a plane by a grid of squares; let us assume that the origin is placed at the corner of one of these squares and that the x and y axes pass through the edges of squares in the grid. There are

rigid symmetries of the grid that leave the origin fixed: clockwise rotations by 0, 1, 2 or 3 right angles, together with reflections in the x-axis, the y-axis, the line y = x and the line y = -x. These are the same symmetries that fix a single square centred at the origin, and mathematicians call this set of symmetries the
. The remarkable thing about the fractal tiling is that it has as much symmetry as an octagon, namely the dihedral group of order 16, which consists of 8 rotations and 8 reflections.

The main results of the paper show that this symmetry doubling happens surprisingly often. More precisely, any lattice tiling of the plane can be re-tiled with tiles having twice as much symmetry as the original tiling, provided that the original tiling was not rhombic. The paper also proves something similar for tilings in
dimensions, provided that the original tiling is not cubic.

counting things again. how did the ancient plutarch come up with 103049? here we learn that the answer was to be found many centuries later...

There are 11 ways to chop a pentagon into pieces by drawing lines between corners - lines that don't intersect.   For a square there are just 3 ways, and for a triangle there's just 1, using no lines at all.

, for an interesting reason.  Hipparchus was one of the best of the ancient Greek astronomers.   He lived around 100 BC, and he discovered the precession of the equinoxes, and invented the 'stereographic projection' - an important way to map a sphere on a plane.

But Plutarch, a philosopher who lived two centuries later, said Hipparchus also showed that the number of “affirmative compound propositions” that can be made from ten “simple propositions” is 103049.
